reviewText:
A disgustingly bad business model on an otherwise fantastic game..

It's such a shame when you come across a fantastic game that's ruined by one of the worst payment models in any game you've ever seen. TheHunter is one of those games. What can you do for free, you ask? Well, you can hunt Mule Deer. That's it. That's all you can do. Shoot Mule Deer with one gun, one type of ammo. The default stuff you start with is all you get. It says you can also hunt Cottontail Rabbits, ah but the catch is you need to buy the correct gun to use in order to be allowed to hunt it. So, Rabbits aren't even free either.

Can you earn enough to eventually buy another gun? Only one other gun is available for purchase using the game's earned currency (called gm$). Every other gun must be bought using real world money (called em$). And that's not all.

Want the privilege to be able to hunt something else? You need to buy licenses. Doesn't sound so bad, does it? Well, they come in 1 day, 7 day, and 28 day variants. Yup, that's right. They expire. So you have to buy them multiple times to continue hunting what you want. Buy a 1 day license but then get called in to work? Congrats! You've just wasted your money! You CAN buy these with gm$, but the costs are so high that you'll be farming Mule Deer for weeks in order to finally be able to experience something else.

Oh but hold on. It's not like each kill you make earns you gm$. Hah! You wish! Nope. The only way to earn gm$ is to complete missions" which range from tracking certain animals
hoursPlayed: among other similar tasks. Doesn't sound so bad

reviewText:
Hello everybody,

I play this game since nearly the beginning, have seen the initial developer go bankrupt and the new developer take over. I have seen month with nothing happening in terms of developments and I have seen the last few month after multiplayer was released with new stuff released every few weeks.

If you love hunting simulations, theHunter for sure is the game you want. It's way more realistic then Cabela's games, it has pretty nice graphics and huge different hunting locations with many, many animals to hunt. Every species feels special and there has not been a really good hunting simulation since Deer Hunter 2005.

- Pricing -
The downside: You need to invest a whole lot of money. To really enjoy the game you need a membership for about 5$ a month. No membership and you can only hunt very few species, need to buy ammo for all but the default rifle and can't create multiplayer games. Sure you can stick with some basic guns, but to take part in competitions and finish missions you need a whole lot of different guns. Each between 3 and 5$. Not to forget, there are tree stands, ground blinds and tents you would like to use sooner or later because there are very few fixed hunting towers on the maps and... yes, each of these items is another 4,50$ from your wallet.

Just a few numbers for you:
All weapons with scopes (not caluclation different skins or premium" skins)
more then 150$

All callers (no decoys
date:
no consumables like scents):
about 20$

Decoys for one full area for each species:
about 30$

Clothing depends on what you want

reviewText:
EDIT: People are actually defending this? Compare the amount of free content to the amount of content you have to pay for. It's unacceptable to make me pay money to access that much content in a free to play game.

It costs nothing to download, but I feel entitled to a refund.

First of all, there was no tutorial for this. I was just thrown in, and expected to know how to hunt. I wandered aimlessly for a while, until I found some tracks. I followed them, and found some more tracks and some scat. There was so much scat, that I began to wonder if this animal was sick. I followed the trail for about one in game hour unril I saw it: a whitetail deer. Living in an area with a lot of rednecks, I was excited. Apparently deer are something you should want to hunt. I readied my rifle, and clicked the fire button. Nothing. Was the left mouse button not the fire button? The right mouse button readied the gun, so I figured the left would fire. Then a message popped up: You don't have the required license to hunt whitetail deer". What? I just spent almost forty real minutes tracking this thing down

reviewText:
I couldnt decide what to write in this review , so im gonna share with you guys my favorite apple pie recipe Enjoy! :D

Pastry

2 cups all-purpose flour

1 teaspoon salt

2/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons shortening

4 to 6 tablespoons cold water

Filling

1/3 to 1/2 cup sugar

1/4 cup all-purpose flour

1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon

1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg

1/8 teaspoon salt

8 cups thinly sliced peeled tart apples (8 medium)

2 tablespoons butter or margarine

1) In medium bowl, mix 2 cups flour and 1 teaspoon salt. Cut in shortening, using pastry blender (or pulling 2 table knives through ingredients in opposite directions), until particles are size of small peas. Sprinkle with cold water, 1 tablespoon at a time, tossing with fork until all flour is moistened and pastry almost cleans side of bowl (1 to 2 teaspoons more water can be added if necessary).

2) Gather pastry into a ball. Divide in half; shape into 2 flattened rounds on lightly floured surface. Wrap in plastic wrap; refrigerate about 45 minutes or until dough is firm and cold, yet pliable. This allows the shortening to become slightly firm, which helps make the baked pastry more flaky. If refrigerated longer, let pastry soften slightly before rolling.

3) Heat oven to 425°F. With floured rolling pin, roll one pastry round into round 2 inches larger than upside-down 9-inch glass pie plate. Fold pastry into fourths; place in pie plate. Unfold and ease into plate, pressing firmly against bottom and side.

4) In large bowl, mix sugar, 1/4 cup flour, the cinnamon, nutmeg and 1/8 teaspoon salt. Stir in apples until well mixed. Spoon into pastry-lined pie plate. Cut butter into small pieces; sprinkle over filling. Trim overhanging edge of pastry 1/2 inch from rim of plate.

5) Roll other round of pastry into 10-inch round. Fold into fourths and cut slits so steam can escape. Unfold top pastry over filling; trim overhanging edge 1 inch from rim of plate. Fold and roll top edge under lower edge, pressing on rim to seal; flute as desired. Cover edge with 2- to 3-inch strip of foil to prevent excessive browning.

6) Bake 40 to 50 minutes or until crust is brown and juice begins to bubble through slits in crust, removing foil for last 15 minutes of baking. Serve warm if desired.

reviewText:
This game is perfect for the adventurous gamer who enjoys spending real money on memberships, buying virtual items and buying the privilege of clicking on things that look different from other things. It comes with a decent selection of weapons - all you have to do is buy some ingame cash with your actual cash. Is a bear threatening your backside? No problem - just buy the bear hunting licence for a few dollars and he'll be toast. Wanna play with friends? That's great - slap some more dollars their way and you're good. As a free-to-play character you get one rifle and you get to hunt a whole two animal types.

The visuals are fantastic for the year 2004 - I especially enjoyed having the animal I was watching at one point twist its head around and give me the bedroom eyes from behind before it vanished into the ether. Then my buddy sank into the river, where his eyes separated from the rest of his head.

The F2P experience is, in short, a complete waste of time.
voteText: 341 of 408 people (84%) found this review helpful 62 people found this review funny

reviewText:
You can only shoot 1 of the 18 animals for free. Solution: pay for hunter licenses.
You can only shoot deer, fox and coyote with the free gun. Solution: pay for more guns.
You want to play with friends in multiplayer. Solution: pay a sub so that your computer and your internet can be used to setup a server.
You don't get the carry capacity to do even semi-long hunts. Solution: pay for extra carry capacity.
You payed for extra carry capacity but you still don't have the carry capacity to do awesome long hunts whole day long. Solution: NONE!!!
You can travel free on maps from lodges but on all maps this is very time consuming with how they were layed out by the developers. Solution: pay for tents and camping equipment.
You don't get free ammo for 32 of 33 weapons in the game. Solution: keep paying money for new ammo (hardcore simulator?) or buy a membership.
You don't like your clothes or the fact animals can see you from miles away because there is no telling which bush actually gives you cover or not. Solution: Pay for clothing items.
You're tired of stalking animals for hours before you get a shot at them. Solution: Pay for callers, decoys, ground stands, tree stands, tripods, scent lures, feeders, bait.

I'm surprised the developers don't ask money for every footstep you take into the game.
If you buy the $15 starter pack, you will be missing tons of guns and all other equipment that are simply needed to enjoy the game. But even if you spend $50 on the biggest starter pack, you still miss many equipment to hunt half the animals in the game and the weapon selection in the biggest package is rather sad (I wouldn't dare to say it was done deliberately to lure you into buying the more fun/better weapons later seperately wasting all the money you gave in the first place on guns that will be gathering dust).


This is the best executed hunter game ever if money grows on your back. We're talking at least €200 here to start enjoying most of the full game. If you really want to hunt in luxury (it's a game, who wouldn't want to?) you'll start looking at a lot more money than that.
The game is easily 8/10. The amount of money you have to throw at the game to actually get to that 8/10 makes it a 1/10 at best.

My library hopefully shows I'm not one to be afraid to spend money on games. But these guys brought it to a level that I have never seen before. Congratulations on surpassing Korean MMO's EW.



Addendum: subscription

And what are people paying subscription for?
Retextured or new weapons? Because you have to pay to get those.
New animals? Because you have to buy licenses to hunt those.
New equipment for the new animals? Nope not that either because you have to pay for all the new callers and feeders and stands.
Multiplayer? Well they did add MP afterwards but it can't be it since an MP game is hosted on our computer with our internet connection. And they didn't spend any effort on making a standalone server or adding any useful filters in the client browser to warrent anything special. That is if you are lucky enough the client browser is working without big lag and there are none of the many connection and disconnection issues.
New clothing? Again these cost money.
New maps? Well it must be maps then since there isn't anything else. So we're paying €35/year for the 4maps? they added in the last 5years. Those are some damn expensive maps!

We're not paying for continued development of the engine either.
- View distance of 210m for weapons that can make accurate shots of 500m.
- Trees that are literally square with highest ingame settings and the leafs are just flat green 'sheets'.
- Game settings can only be adjusted outside of the game.
- A fox and pheasant can just walk next to eachother because it's a fairytale land where all animals are big friends.
- Mouse often feels laggy/jaggy however you want to call it. Many people have these small FPS drop problems and support just ignores it all.
- The surface has the most annoying edges which makes it very awkward to crawl up to an animal and finding an angle where your gun gets enough depression.
- Floating rocks, plants and trees everywhere you look on the map.
I can go on further with a list of technical stupidities that were allready old tech 5years ago.

reviewText:
I really had some good few hours. This was the first time I played a hunting game and I really expected nothing from it.
But I was surprised how how good the game was from its technical view. It's not the best looking game but the flora and fauna really got some love and detail, the sound is awesome and the lighting and sun effects are also really nice.
Really felt like being in the woods.
Now here's the negative trait. This game's free2play model is nowhere near anything you might consider as free to play and fair. Everything costs a lot of money and either you join the membership or you have a walking simulator (you're only allowed to hunt rabbits and mule deers).
It's more like a demo when you don't plan to invest money. The game even calls you a guest.  And oh boy, the pricing is insane.
Probably a good hunting game, but I can't recommend it. It's a shame cause it was really an atmospheric experience for me.
That said I think if you are a really passionate hunter in real life you would probably gladly spend money on this one and you would probably go nuts about all people who complain abouth the subscription model.

reviewText:
Holy money hungry game.  Everything except deer (a certain type of deer) is locked behind pay walls.  I'm not talking about low pay walls, I'm talking about high pay walls.

I just about bought the 3 month membership for all licenses because I thought.. Why not, looks like it could be fun.  But then I went to the store to check out the guns and stuff I could buy.  Well EVERY SINGLE GUN costs EM which is bought with REAL dollars.  There is no way at all for you to buy these guns unless you open your wallet.  Basic guns cost 5 dollars each and better ones well over 10.

I don't mind the freemium models and actually spend a lot of cash on them lol.  But I have NEVER seen a game that is so blatently money grabbing as this one.  It is absolutely astounding how much  money they want you to pay to have access to the full game.  You could spend 100's on 100's of dollars and still not have unlocked all the content (and its not because there is a ton of content..).  Plus no matter how much you play you will not be able to unlock it without using a ton of REAL money.

This game should be removed from Free to play because all it does is give you a VERY limited demo (I didn't have a license to shoot the anmal I found in the starter area) and then want money to do anything.

Dev's like these should be BANNED from steam.

reviewText:
This game looks like it has potential and is fun. However the 'Free-To-Play' label is misleading. After downloading the 2GB game I looked forward to shoot some helpless animals but, as soon-as I loading in the open world I had no idea what to do or get started. No controls or help menu was available in-game, so I had to resort to an online video on the internet.

After getting used to the main controls I ventured out to hunt… I found a trail of a Blacktail deer and ID’d it with my gadget. A pop-up appeared saying I need a licence or a membership to hunt this animal. I then looked up to see what I could kill. Apparently there are only 2 animals you can hunt and 1 weapon you can use in this F2P game.

I now know this Free-to-play is actuallya Fee To Play and Pay-To-Win game, with micro transactions, donations and memberships everywhere.

Sorry, but I looked forward to play this game and not Pay-To-Win… It has really good graphics quality though.

Rating: 2/10

reviewText:
Thats f*cking it! I'm going to write a review.. This is my first review and probably my last because if I write a review, trust me I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off as hell! And hell, am I ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of now!

As you can see I played 700+ hours in this game and long story short, i DO NOT RECOMMEND this game to anyone. Believe me the game is worth paying money for, it’s WORTH IT’S MONTHLY prescription and please if you are here to play the game for free just turn around the way you came, this is not for you. It is only free to play as a DEMO, you get extremely limited options and playability. If you want to put money in this game it is definitely worth it IF NOT FOR;

1)	The lack of multiplayer compatibility; (300 servers and only 5 you can connect to due to “could not connect to host”, “host has quit the game”(server still in server list 30 mins after the host quit the game already),  “lost connection to host”, server of my buddy up and running (TeamSpeak confirmed) and not in server list for about 45 mins, “error 16005” “I GOT IT”, “error 404 developer’s f*cks not found”
2)	Abundant bugs (which NEVER EVER GET FIXED) and I’m not talking about the bugs previously discussed as connection bugs, I’m talking about bugs of getting stuck in scenery, floating ducks that stay stuck in the air (due to connection error again though), animals stuck behind trees and rocks, animals that have died on player side but not harvestable because of server misalignment,…,.., and the list keeps going and going
3)	The developers don’t give a f*ck *(this is the most important part for my experience); They keep hiring new people with great new ideas about a new species like the “polar bear” (which you’re not allowed to f*cking shoot!, PUT YOUR DEVELOPING TIME IN SOMETHING USEFULL YOU IDIOT DEVELOPERS), persistent problems with connections which have been an issue and have been addressed numerous times by the community but have been left aside because getting new weapons and new animals is more profitable, priority is giving above all to getting a new skin on a new weapon which costs you another 5$ because the colour has changed on the weapon or because the colour of the animals has changed.
4)	The game is not even near a complete stage, with its developers building on a broken game and making it more unplayable than it already is. They keep adding sh*t without fixing previous errors and by doing so they make the implementation of anything REALY worth it get drowned by the everlasting errors and bugs that follow it. The implementation of something good is followed by weeks, if not months, of issues resolving from this add-on and by getting the public back to the game the implement something new, which starts the hole sh*t train from the beginning.

If you have not already turned around and decided not to look at this game, I tell you again, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME OR PUT MONEY IN TO IT IN IT’S CURRENT STATE. I don’t think this current state is going to change to anything good in the foreseeable future as the developers just don’t give a f*ck or are trying but are so inexperienced that my 6yo niece can make a better running game. This game has potential but it should have been a Steam GreenLight game and not a finished one and the enormous ego that makes the developers not think about gameplay but all about money made me vote this game as DO NOT RECOMMEND.

I hope to god that the developers are reading my review and start working on the issues that need to be fixed to make this game worth it. If they are not, be wary of my next review, as I will be even more ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off as I keep playing this game in the hope it becomes something it should be.

(PS: this review was 16 pages long but I removed a lot of the swearing, reducing it to 2. If you read this all please rate funny or helpful in the hope it reaches the developers of Expensive Worlds)

reviewText:
The steam page may boast the idea that  theHunter  is a  free  game. However this is more or less a downright lie. TheHunter is a game that is designed to make the free to play version of theHunter be extremely linear and boring but show enough promise into what the game  could be  if you payed for the membership. These micro transactions are thrown upon you at almost every second of this game. Want to play with a friend? Nope you have to pay! Want to use a bunch of cool weapons? Nope you have to pay! Can I at least hunt and kill alot of animail's? Nope! Without membership you can only kill and select amount of animals.

Even if the shady transactions and free to play model were not present it doesnt get rid of the fact that theHunter never stops being a boring and extremely glitchy game. Actully shooting an animal is near impossible due to the very laggy movement. I found myself having a hell of a lot more fun using the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ brick breaker app on the hunters phone in game than actully hunting, which is never a good sign. Hunting games can be fun and interesting but theHunter with lack of a better work screwed everything up and created a pile of ♥♥♥♥ which is a disgrace to good games trying to get on steam these days.

-AUS ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)

reviewText:
I noticed theHunter was free to play so thought I'd give it a go. This is how my experience went:

I load up the game and jump straight into the hunt! I familiarise myself with the controls and get ready to begin.

I hike through miles of woodland, meticulously scanning the area for my prey. These are my woods. I am the apex                     predator. A god among mindless furry beasts.

After what seems like hours, I see it. My prey. A 33.4kg female Mule deer. It hasn't seen me yet. My primal hunter instincts activate and I stealthily approach.

I zero in on the deer. My deer. My trophy. It is in my crosshairs, I hold my breath, ready to fire, I was born for this. Everything I had accomplished in life leading me here, to this very moment...

Balls! It suddenly spooks, and trys to run. I panic and let out a squeal, firing blindly. I see blood spraying everywhere. I had hit it, but the poor thing just keeps on running, trailing blood the whole way.

Still panicking, I chase after the deer, following the trail of its blood. After 10 mins I find it...

The deer, my deer, has collapsed from exhaustion in an alarmlingly large pool of it's own blood.

It's in so much pain.

It looks up at me.

It knows.

Please
date:
kill me." It tells me with its eyes.

Those eyes.

I start to cry.

I can't do it.

I walk away.

I uninstall the game.

I still have nightmares about the deer.

I start drinking heavily and consuming opiates to cope with the pain.

It helps me forget.

Life will never be the same.
10/10 would suffer from PTSD and ruin life again."

reviewText:
TL;DR Great game, horrible pay to play system.

This game would be great, if you just had to pay, say, $20 a month and have access to all content, but this is not the case.
First, you pay about $3 a month to be able have infinite liscenses and shoot everything. But you can't shoot everything because the starting rifle only has specific species it can shoot. In order to get more powerful guns, you must pay real life cash. The conversion rate is rougly $1 to 100 ingame currency, but many weapons cost more than 500.

This means you must pay $5 for an ingame gun along with the $3 a month to shoot a virtual deer that will most likely see/smell you if you don't pay for ingame camo which is even more expensive than the gun.

reviewText:
Most of these reviews are compltely inaccurate, mostly in the form of sarcasm.
Facts:
Alphafact: I have killed everything in the game without paying a single penny. (read below)
1. This is a free to play game. It costs absolutely nothing to play this game.
2. You are given a .243 riffle, and a single shot 12 guage shotgun, both with unlimited ammo.
3. You can go into any map of the game. An immersive and realistic environment that sits on my top 3 most realistic of all time, in any game i have ever played. 2x Geforce GTX 970. At full detail levels. On the other hand player avatars can use a realism update, but the animals definately do not, and as this is a human vs animal game that is what counts.
4. You can hunt Whitetail deer, pheasant, and 3 varieties of rabbit. (to start; fact is it cost nothing to hunt the other animals)
5. The ballistics and damage models are by far the most accurate in any hunting game to date. Source: My opinion; I have hunted just about everything legal on the north american continent in the last 35 years, Including 6 Alaska hunts. and i have played Cabela's [titles here] hunting games as well.
5. You can take part in in-game missions (quests) that reward you with in game currency (gms) To purchase perishable supplies like scents and baits, as well as licenses and ammo. (pssst this is the how-to)

Biggest problem with the game is:
1. Most people dont know what the hell they are doing they are running around like they are playing Battlefield 3 or Gears of war....this is the playstyle that they are failing at with this game. While you don't have to be a ninja to aquire a target in this game, you will need some patience and a little stealth to get anything in the trophy range (hello...real animals spook as do these, if they hear or smell you, you probably wont see them)
2. You arent getting any full auto weapon in this game. Every shot (except those made at the range) are tallied to your permanent record. The only semi-autos in game are a few select shotguns.
3. No grenades, sachel charges, land mines or tow missles, sorry.
4. People think programers work for free. They don't and this game wouldn't exist if players didn't take shortcuts" and buy weaposn
date:
gear and licenses and instead used the gm method of hunting to get the very same things.


Bottom line: This game is free to play and you can hunt everything in the game without ever spending a dime of real currency. If you cannot do that
recommended: you are doing something entirely wrong and likely not in the scope of the game i.e. hunting and harvesting game.\n\nIf anyone really needs any more clarification on the how to hunt all animals in this game as a guest
hoursPlayed: send me a message and i'll try and simplify it further for you."

reviewText:
theHunter Review
A disgustingly bad business model on an otherwise fantastic game..

It's such a shame when you come across a fantastic game that's ruined by one of the worst payment models in any game you've ever seen. TheHunter is one of those games. What can you do for free, you ask? Well, you can hunt Mule Deer. That's it. That's all you can do. Shoot Mule Deer with one gun, one type of ammo. The default stuff you start with is all you get. It says you can also hunt Cottontail Rabbits, ah but the catch is you need to buy the correct gun to use in order to be allowed to hunt it. So, Rabbits aren't even free either.

Can you earn enough to eventually buy another gun? Only one other gun is available for purchase using the game's earned currency (called gm$). Every other gun must be bought using real world money (called em$). And that's not all.

Want the privilege to be able to hunt something else? You need to buy licenses. Doesn't sound so bad, does it? Well, they come in 1 day, 7 day, and 28 day variants. Yup, that's right. They expire. So you have to buy them multiple times to continue hunting what you want. Buy a 1 day license but then get called in to work? Congrats! You've just wasted your money! You CAN buy these with gm$, but the costs are so high that you'll be farming Mule Deer for weeks in order to finally be able to experience something else.

Oh but hold on. It's not like each kill you make earns you gm$. Hah! You wish! Nope. The only way to earn gm$ is to complete missions" which range from tracking certain animals
hoursPlayed: among other similar tasks. Doesn't sound so bad

reviewText: What a great game. Going out in the wild with your friends and tracking down all kinds of game in the forest. The game is very beautiful and nice. I was astonished by the level of complexity and detail put into this game and still maintaining nice visuals and aesthetic. That is until you want to progress past shooting Mule deers in the beginner area. To get anywhere in the game you have to pay out of your pockets, they claim to have a method where you just do some surveys and get in-game currency. This sneaky survey system is not something you want to touch with a 10-feet pole. Remember those adds on shady websites? Win an iPad? Lusty girls in your neighbourhood? Yes, long lists of these adds, that they want you to click and register on. If you for some reason would do that, there is a 33% chance that you MIGHT get a little bit of in-game currency. For some reason they decided to put in two different currencies, currency you can get for doing ridiculously hard tasks and the one i explained above (real money). This other currency, gm$ is utterly USELESS, there is about 10.000 available for each player, and you can use them for two things: Ammo, for guns that you don't own, for game that you can't kill and for licences (1 Licence for 30 days is about 8500, nearly all of the available gm$). Now you might think that buying a bit of ingame currency can't be that bad. Yes, yes it can. First you will need a membership, the smallest one is 15 euros which allows you to kill all animals. Then you need a gun, add atleast another 5 euros depending on the gun. Then you will need calls for the animals you want to hunt. Add another 5 euros, and here we are, for 25$ you can play the game to some extend for 30 days. TheHunter is such a great game to play with your friends, but to get anything above what a demo would deliver you would have to empty your pockets into an endless hole. Please, if you would make a one time purchase option I and others would gladly pay up. If you dont want that you can go with the TF2 system, pay for an item above 5 euros and get acces to the full game, and then you can buy more things if you want to speed things up. Atleast make it possible to progress without paying. If you did this or the one time purchase i would play and support this title again, but with the current system and business practises i cannot support the game, it's disgusting.

reviewText:
This game looks beautiful and plays really well. It has some major flaws though.

First I'd like to state that I never bought the game, but played it as a free to play.

First thing is the wind, the wind always blows from the south-west, making it quite boring and inefficient starting from any souther point on a map in my opinion. While a small problem, it is still an issue making the game dull at that part. A wind change every X hour or having it randomly set to one thing at the start of a map would be better.

The biggest issue is the microtransaction part. As a free to play game you can only hunt mule deer and cottontail rabbits. You get all the equipment for the mule deers straight away, but in order to get the weapon required for cottontail rabbit, you have to go through microtransactions or watch ads/register on sketchy sites to obtain in game currency. There is a currency in the game that you can earn by doing missions, like shooting and confirming the kill of an animal or tracking and spotting a certain animal. But this currency cannot be used for buying weapons, only ammunition and other items such as scent removers etc.

Paying the subscription allows you to hunt every single animal, and some packs give you weapons and sights to get started. But none offer said air rifle for use on rabbits, mallards or pheasants. I find this a huge problem as I wanted to shoot rabbits.

The game could go very far if it had better ways of obtaining things. The ads for currency should be removed, everything should be purchasable with the free to play currency and it should be possible to obtain it from successfully shooting and killing animals that give points (mostly male animals)

reviewText:
Don't bother downloading this game unless you are hardcore right into hunting sims. Hunting sims, not games..

So this is not an arcade hunting game whatsoever. You will spend a lot of time running around tracking or even trying to find anything moving at all. The graphics are actually pretty nice looking, and the game runs very smoothly.

The main problem with this game is that it is listed as Free to Play. It should really say Demo with paid content. or Pay to Play.

You start out being able to only shoot mule deer. Doing this will earn you points (that don't actually do anything, it seems). There are quite a few animal types in the game, but if you want to go after anything other than mule deers, (oh yeah, rabbits too) than you have to get a license to hunt them. How do you get a license? Well, by spending in game money. How do you get in game money you ask? Well, you can do missions... 3 of them. Once these 3 missions are done you will get a small portion of in-game money, however, not enough to actually buy anything. These are not daily missions either. They don't reset ever, once they are done they are done. The only way to unlock more missions is to buy a license to hunt a new animal.. So how else can you get in-game money then? Well, the only way is to buy it with real money. This is not free to play... this is actually more expensive a game than most AAA big name games.

If you want to play the full game expect to pay a ton of cash, and then, only for whatever time limit you have bought for your licenses, then you have to rebuy them again. Lol

Terrible terrbible terrible pay model. One of the worst I have ever seen. I'm not saying it should be totally free, but this is absolutely just not the way to do it.

I don't recommend this game at all.

reviewText:
There are so many animals in this game its like you are acually hunting. Spend hours hunting down animals alone or with your friends. Hunt down deer, bears, ducks, pheasants, rabbits, boars, ect. The amount of hours that any player could have put in to this game would have been amazing.

Sounds like a good game right, well if its a good game why am i not recommending it, well here is the reason why. The store page is lieing, to you there is nothing in this game that makes it free-2-play. The 4 hours i spent playing this game i was so confused on why i couldn't shoot a boar THAT WAS RIGHT IN FRONT OF ME. Turns out you need a liecense for almost every animal. You can only kill 2 animals if you are a free-2-play player, which is mule deer and rabbits (which in my opinion the hardest animals to find). I spent 2 hours looking for mule deers, I looked up guides, I tried different approaches, and still couldn't even see one. i was following a mule deer's tracks for a full hour and everytime i would get close it would run away (now keep in mind I was crouching the entire time and I didnt even get to see the damn thing). Also, while I was looking for the mule deer i found a whitetail deer, a pheasant, and a boar, WHICH WERE EASY KILLS. So this the games logic, I have to pay in order to click on animals. Yes that makes so much sense, my god i would rather go hunting in real life. Oh and i didnt even get to the equipent, guess how many weapons you get, just guess, ONE. It makes no sense to me how you only get ONE weapon in a hunting game. Ok let me tell you everything you get when you first start the game. You get a sniper rifle, a huntermate (a GPS/tracker), a mule deer caller, a camera, and binoculars. Now you might think that that is exactly what you need to go hunting. Well your wrong, because the full 4 hours i was playing the game i kept finding everything other than mule deer. Oh and I almost forgot mule deers are only found on one map, and there are i believe 8 maps. So let me get this straight there are 8 maps in this game, the animals that you are able to kill are only available in 1 map, and you only get 2 animals that you are able to kill. Yeah this is definatly free-2-play. Oh yeah also, if you want to be able to kill all the animals in the game you have to get a license. If you want to know something similar to this system, its like Xbox Live. You pay 14.99 for a 3 month license. WTF thats criminal now a days, now if you are the kind person that doesnt mind paying, then thats great this game is for you. But its still very stupid that you have to do such a thing like that.

Hey Expansive Worlds and Avalanche Studios, let me teach you something about free-2-play.

In order to make a good free-2-play game you must be able to make sacrifcises. Sacrificises such as being able to hunt down every animal in 1 map (not 2 you greedy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s), be able to give the player 1 of every weapon, and a caller for those animals. Now is that so hard. If you listen to this review and do what i say this will definately make this game, The Best Hunting Game Ever Made. It has the potential.

The final verdict for this game is:

3/10

and if you listen to my suggetions it would probably make the game at least:

7/10

Think about it

reviewText:
Feels like a good game being hijacked by Wall Street.

1. It's a demo, not a F2P game by any regard. There's no logical way to progress without paying.

2. It's subscription-based despite being mainly a singleplayer game with token multiplayer.

3. Even if you subscribe, there are semi-arbitrary limitations on what guns can be used on what animal, forcing you to A. Buy two more guns B. Buy a shotgun and then continuously buy special ammo. C. Buy a bow, which is far harder to use than any other weapon. Either way, you either pay more or pay some and gimp yourself.

4. Even if you buy the subscription and then guns you've only made the game passable. Forget about accessing any other guns, utilities or clothing without paying even more. So be prepared for about $18 just to get the very basics, and at only a 3-month lease to boot.

5. The retail version of the game right now is about $16, for which you get 7 weapons, 6 months subscription and assorted goodies. The 'Starter Pack' closest to that one is $32 for 4 weapons, 6 months subscription and assorted goodies. Here's a hint. The first one is a decent price. The second one is deliberate milking of its customers for even less content.


So yes, the game itself is something I'd definitely see myself playing, but even after subscribing I can't motivate myself to throw more and more money at it to get anywhere. It's a nice enough game, with well-made environments and soundscape, but without a campaign of any kind or more elaborate multiplayer experience it's more of a 'pick it up every now and then to relax' type of game. Which is fine, but completely hampered by the constant money grabbing - as a one-off I'd happily pay $25-40 for it, but for that kind of money now you'd barely get 10% of the full game and a subscription ending
to watch out for.

[edit] Turns out that even if you have the licensing and the appropriate gun, you need to shell out more cash for hunting some species (e.g. mallards) for decoys and whatnot, or get shafted. Neat.

reviewText:
First thing i have to mention is, this game is DEFINITELY pay to play.
F2P is a LIE,

This review is made on the mindset that you paid upfront anywhere from 20usd-40usd for Either the Wayfarer Bundle or the PathFinder Bundle.
-----------------------------------
The Difference between Wayfarer and PathFinder

The only things you need to consider are-
Another 20usd for a silent bow and a backpack.
The extra 3 months membership is not something you should consider.
If you want to try using a silent bow to hunt animals ,and would like to carry more than 1 weapon, then you should consider the PathFinder Pack.
------------------------------------
Now then,
Why is the hunter fun/not fun.
+Authentic* hunting (Close enough i think, i never hunted IRL)
+Multiple animal varieties
+Multiple Types of guns to use(Rifles,Shotguns,Bows mainly)

-Very slow game
-a Kill can be anywhere from 20 minutes to 90minutes, depending on your skill level and luck
-an Animal might survive after getting shot and escape so far you might not find it, wasting another 10-30minutes
+That said a kill is more gratifying because of this
-----------------------------------
Should you buy a bundle and play this game?

If you want to find a game where you can have fun killing animals easily-     No
If you just want to kill animals-    Maybe
- if you have the patience
If you would try and experience a new type of gaming, of Slow pace and patience-Yes
If you are willing to crouch/walk 85% of the time, listening to nature, scouting for animals-    Yes
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TLDR
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Game is slow, expensive, and might not be worth your time.
But a kill you gain after hunting it for 30-90 minutes feels great.

EDIT- i realise i could get 5 kills in a 72minute session, so if you have a decent amount of skill in the game , you are able to get consistent kills every 10-20 minutes or so

reviewText:
If you're willing to pay the monthly fees, you're going to have a good time. It's a fun game that can kill a lot of your time. Probably the best hunting simulator in the market.

However, if you're going to play for free, which is how this game was marketed, you're going to have a bad time, because all you're going to do is go around, find an animal, attemp to shoot it and get a message saying that you have to pay to be able to hunt it. You're only allowed to hunt one type of animal, and it's moderately hard to find one, let alone hunt it.

Do I recommend it for how it was marketed? Of course not.
Would I recommend it if it were Buy2Play and not Pay2Play disguised as free to play? Absolutely.


Don't mind the low play time. I used to play it in the standalone launcher before it was on Steam. I decided to check back if anything has changed. It didn't. They only added more packs to be bought.

reviewText: As so many reviewers before me I have to demand to get rid of this F2P tag. You have to pay real money on a subscription based model to play the game as the developers intented it. reviewText:
I have been searching for a good hunting game for awhile now and this gem popped up. Its a beautifully crafted game and you can tell there was love put into it. It is a solid title, however, I cannot enjoy the Hunter because I am constantly stopped by pay walls with it. Microtransactions are abundant and the game takes the fun out of it being a video game by making you have to pay for (like in real life) rounds, rifles, pistols, holsters, hunting licenses (which are temporary) and all sorts of other manner of hunting equipment as well.

Its a great game, it could use vehicles, but the major downside is how all the equipment is blocked by constant cash fees. You can't just go out there and hunt whatever you like without paying the developer something and that is definetaly not what I am looking for in a hunting simulator. I will say you start with some basic equipment and are able to hunt hare and whitetail deer (correct me if I am wrong).

I could understand and appreciate mechanics that dealt with ingame currency by rewarding you with cash for trophy kills, but that is not the case. I wish this was a standalone title, but sadly it is not. There is a multiplayer aspect to it and I really did not delve into it. If this is a MMO-like/multiplayer game with a deep community I could slightly understand the microtranscation fees. I still however in my good conscience cannot reccommend this game.

If there is a standalone version where I can just buy the whole product and am not blocked by microtranscations, I would gladly pay for it. It would be well worth it in my honest opinion, but until that point this game is a no from me.

reviewText:
This review mostly discusses the main issue the game has for most people – the pricing model. If you are looking for a gameplay or more balanced review, please Google for a “Let’s play” video or read another review instead. The positive recommendation only applies if you deem the pricing model as discussed acceptable.

First things first - This title is not Free to Play.If you are looking for a free to play hunting title i have to start this review with some bad news: this game is not free to play by most interpretations of the term Free to play". As a limited member you can do the following:
You can enter all the reserves and wander around.
You receive one basic rifle
date: a scope and unlimited ammunition refills for that rifle. You will also receive a deer caller.\nYou can only hunt Cottontail rabbits and Mule Deers. Hunting all other animals is prohibited in the sense that you cannot do so at all. You can see them
recommended: but shooting them is not possible.Unlike other free to play games you cannot feasibly unlock new content by playing the game a lot or by being good at it. You are stuck with what you have and that is it – and it’s admittedly not too much.\n\nThe pricing model.So
hoursPlayed: you made it past the initial post explaining the game is not free to play and might be considering picking the game up? In that case
voteText: let us talk about the games pricing model and what it entails. The games pricing model is twofold: there are both subscriptions and items purchases.\n\nSubscription:  Subscription starts at 9.99 for a 3 month period which is arguably quite good compared to most MMO's. In exchange for your subscription you will receive unlimited ammunition for all the weapons you own
helpfulPercent: and a license to hunt all species of animals in the game. It is also possible to buy ammunition and animal hunting licenses as separate items though the monetary exchange rate for this is fairly bad in comparison. (But perhaps worthwhile if you are a very casual player)\nItems: Buyable items cover a broad range of possibilities. There is weapons
votesHelpful: scopes
votesTotal: clothing
votesFunny: deployables (Hunting towers)
commentsCount: utilities (Animal callers
column16: storage increasing backpack) and temporally power-ups (Wind indicators
column17: facial paint et cetera).\n\nExcept for the power-ups all items are permanent once bought
column18: with the caveat being that you will need an animal license and ammunition to hunt specific animals. There is an additional caveat as well: Each weapon can only be used on a subset of the animals in the game - you cannot use a pistol on a bear or a rifle on a pheasant for example. If you want to hunt all animals you will need to buy multiple weapons. The utilities sold are somewhat more optional though a huge convenience: callers enable you to coax animals them out of hiding or locate them
column19: while specific clothing will provide superior camouflage thus fewer running animals as you try to sneak upon them.\n\nBottom line? Expect to buy a membership and - depending on playing preference - one or more weapons
column20: scopes and clothing if you wish to fully enjoy everything the game has to offer. The cheapest variety would be buying the wayfarer pack for about 15 Euro's; this includes 3 months of membership
column21: a shotgun
column22: a pistol with scope and some consumables. The shotgun itself is - with different ammo types - able to take down every type of animal in the game.\n\nAlternative you can do some research and find yourself a relatively cheap combination of items that allows you to hunt virtually everything the way you want it. Still
column23: don't be surprised if you end up forking 20-30 bucks over initially if you chose this route (that figure includes a 3 month membership).\n\nFinal thoughts.Despite the games price model arguably being steep I personally find myself enjoying the game quite a bit
column24: so for me it is well worth the triple-a equivalent price I spend on it so far. Considering my current time invested
column25: the subscription fee and my lack of a need to buy new items the game will be cheaper than a regular subscription MMO if I keep playing it another month or two
column26: while spending a similar amount of time on it.\n\nThat said: I can only advice the game to people who – like me – enjoy hunting simulations quite a bit. If you plan on picking up the game you should be able to live with the thought of having to possibly do a relatively sizable investment initially
column27: followed by a fairly mild recurrent billing scheme. It is not a good pickup for people looking exclusively for a free to play title due to the rather sharp limitations and the inability to unlock content by playing a lot or being good. Still
column28: the game itself is a lot of fun if you like hunting sims. If you can stomach the need for payment and don't mind doing some research into the items you want i can hearthily recomment it.\n\nAddendum - How to make the most out of your game without paying a dime: There is an excellent guide on the forums by Maverick that discusses the topic of getting the most out of the game without paying a dime for it. The method discussed will not grant access to all content indefinitely: You will be reliant on missions and counting your bullets. Even so it will allow you to access more content (Including hunting other animals) on a temporary basis. If you are strapped for cash but really want to play more of the game the suggestions in it may be a viable alternative - at least for a while."

reviewText:
After the apocalypse, Steve and his family moved to the coast of Norway. All was good and well until the family ran out of food supplies. Steve, who had worked in an office before the apocalypse, didn't really know how to use a gun, and had never killed an animal. But his family was starving, so he decided to give it a shot.
Steve found an old rifle and som bullets in the cabin where they were living, and set out to find some food.

He hadn't been searching for long, when suddenly a wild boar appeared. Steve laid down, pointed the hole-y end towards the animal, and pulled the trigger.  Nothing happened.  He was shocked at first, but later realised that the gun didn't want to cooperate beacuse he DIDN'T OWN THE LICENSE TO KILL THE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ THING.

Dissappointed, Steve set out to find some other animal. After a while a Peasant appeared.  Steve pointed the gun towards it, and pulled the trigger. Nothing happened again. HE DIDN'T OWN THE LICENSE TO KILL PEASANTS.

No matter how he tried, Steve couldn't find an animal that he owned the license to kil..

After a couple of days he was awfully thirsty, hungry and stressed out. That gun started to look very very compelling.

He pointed it towards his head, pulled the trigger, and nothing happened. HE DIDN'T OWN THE LICENSE TO KILL HIMSELF.

Instead he decided to jump of a cliff, and shortly after that his family starved to death.

THE END.

Seriously though, are there any animals that you're actually allowed to kill in this game? Havent found any yet, and it's annoying me to death :P

reviewText: This is hands down the most realistic hunting simulator available today. It's not easy and it's not cheap. But nothing even comes close in the hunting game genre. Yeah, it gets negative reviews from people who either have no clue about hunting or can’t afford the game. But it's an awesome game if you like to hunt or think that you’d like to hunt. The landscapes are immense, detailed, and very realistic. Each of the many maps is a work of art. The sounds are realistic and captivating. I wish it weren’t so expensive to play and maintain membership.  But, once you have all of your favorite gear, the membership fee really isn’t too bad considering what I’ve already said ^^.  If there were something better for less I'd definitely be interested. But I've looked and there isn't. So until then this is my hunting game of choice. It's free to try so why not try it and see what makes this the best hunting simulator available today.

reviewText:
Ok then - theHunter.

It's rivalling in terms of hours played my other big favourite of the moment, DayZ, and I'd like to tell you why.

Firstly I am a real life hunter and shooter, but living in the UK access to real weapons and hunting isn't always easy. So when I saw this game for free, I thought it's worth giving a go. I haven't seen another game in this niche for 10 years, so I was keen to see what it offers.

I'm going to deal with the free to play issue. This game can be played for free. You can access all areas of the reserves straight away, and beautiful they are. Yes you are given one weapon/scope only, and are restricted to one species of deer to start with. However if you play well and complete missions you can earn enough in game currency to buy another weapon with which you can then hunt all animals in the game if you buy the appropriate license also with in game currency earned through missions.

Yes there is downloadable content to buy - if you want to - but it's not at all necessary for the enjoyment of the game. I compare it to a well known MMO tank game; you can do it all for free if you want and earn your way to stuff in game play or you can add real money and do it quicker and funner. TheHunter's the same - it gives you the option to use real money if you really want to.

Pricing if you want to use real cash? Well it's minimal. Yes there is the option to buy a membership which for me is 8 English pence a day giving me licenses for all animals on the reserves plus free reloads of ammo. In terms of £ spent to hours played, as I have bought some extras, I'm on about £40 for over 200 hours, and I can see the hours going up and the £ spent staying at about £40. Considering I was charged £1 to aprk for 30 minutes today in town, I don't find this bad value for money at all.

Game play and graphics are ok - I do find it very immersive with TrackIR and Dolby 7.1 headphones. 60fps at highest graphic settings doesn't strain my middle of the road desk top PC.

What makes this game a challenge is that stalking and fieldcraft are probably more important than the shooting element. This is not some sort of immersive shooting gallery. Game can be elusive, wary, spookable, and even dangerous. If all you require is a game to blast holes in things try Sniper Elite.

The only downside for me is that the designers have had to make some gameplay approximations and simplifications which make the game less realistic, and less of a challenge. The most notable one for me is that the rifle trajectories are effectively flat, and range finding isn't really part of the game as your encounter ranges tend to be well under 50 metres. There's no wind effect on the shot either, so real life skills of range finding, usind hold over for range, and allowing for the wind don't appear here which is a shame.

Game play summary: you will spend a lot of time walking slowly from cover to cover straining your ears and eyes for the signs of animals which you can then track and if you get it right you will eventually see them and get in a position to shoot. A critic called it a walking simulator - sounds like he was a poor hunter as stealth is the key.

So thinking of trying it? Well all you have to lose is the download time to your disc. If you like the first couple of hours you'll probably decide to splash a little cash for a basic membership to give you quicker access to hunting species other than the free mule deer.

I've seen a review below where someone makes out that if you want to play the game you need to buy this and buy that and the sums run into large amounts of $. It's not so. You do not need to buy every bit of kit in the game - one shotgun with its birdshot, buckshot and solid slug will let you take on every single species on the map.

So that's it for me. It is a good hunting simulator. There is Gucci gear available for real £ but you can do a lot with a very little £. You can do massive amounts with no £ at all as long as you accept:

a) you need to work your way up the game to earn in game currency
b) you need to use the right skills to do this - play like a CoD buffoon and you'll never succeed
c) that people with real £ can buy goodies if they want to without stopping the game being free to play
d) that there is no 'win' in this game other than the satisfaction you get from hunting with skill

reviewText:
PRELUDE: If you're mature and appreciate high quality games continue reading. The rating on the review is because of immature idiots who want everything for free - got nothing to do with the game. If you're a spoiled immature brat wanting more handouts to go with your welfare cheque, mark it down and ♥♥♥♥ off. Don't bother with entitlement whining in the comments, I'll just kill it.

..oo00oo..

Now, the game.

- GRAPHICS -
This is gorgeous. A 6.00am start at Redfeather had me mesmerised. There are some placing issues, grass and trees above ground etc. but it's really only aesthetics and does little to detract gameplay.

With my trusty 670gtx/i7/8Gb rig this game shines with only minor fan speedup when scene changing. A steady 60fps with only minor tearing (I haven't bothered changing the default yet so could probably be sorted easily enough).

Very easy to look at and the animalation (now there's a word) is very attractive. Slightly robotic at times but hey, if we had 500,000 vectors to plot per animal we couldn't play without a Cray.

- SOUND -
There could be a little more control over some of the ambients, eg: ocean waves, as sound is a critcal and tactile sense in this game and some of it gets over the top. Rain, wind etc. is good and animal calls, while lacking in some bearing seperation, is true to form.

And the guns? Wow. Crank it people. It might take 2 hours of tracking before you fire but I get great delight hearing the .308 reverb off the valley walls. My kids, avid fans all, bounce off their chair! The bang-ratchet-bang of the pump action while pheasant shooting is as sweet as.

(Err.... an 11.00pm .308 shot scored me some wife-wrath so headphones people!)

- GAMEPLAY -
If holding shift + W is your only way to get somewhere this is NOT your thing. If the destination is more important than the journey or you're expecting a gluttony of shootables"
date: DO NOT BUY.\n\nThis requires patience and lots of it
recommended: much of it is tedium. This is hunting. You are a hunter. Stealth. Cover. Shadows. Crouching. Camoflauge. Downwind. ALL of this comes into play.  I've even suggested on the forums that you need to move like YOU are the hunted for best results.\n\nAnimals
hoursPlayed: particularly those munched on by predators have an uncanny sense of smell and hearing. And it IS fascinating to watch animals through a scope pausing
voteText: sniffing and treading lightly. "Wary skittishness" has been modelled beautifully and really adds to the sense of the hunters plight... Let's face it
helpfulPercent:
we're blundering lunkheads in natures true arena and you'll pay the price for it.

-Shooting.
In RL
votesHelpful: I have probably loosed close to 10
votesTotal: 000 rounds. Mostly night shooting for foxes and roos. As a staunch user of the .243 in that era I took great delight in how well this acts
votesFunny: sounds and plays like a .243 ingame. I can "feel" the shoulder kick and smell the powder. (I know
commentsCount: it's psychosomatic but you get what I'm saying....)\n\nScope tracking is well mimiced and looking downrange for a headshot @ 150m is frustratingly difficult. Zoom capabilities are also true-to-form in that higher zoom will produce greater scope movement. Nice work in this department. Note that there are many scopes
column17:
many aimed (yck yck) at quality shooting and range judgement.

- The shotty is divine albeit a rather blunt instrument.
- The .30 is popular and goes off like a firecracker on steroids.
- The Anshutz .308 -a spend money on it- gun has just entered my inventory and is a darling to use. I linked it up with a 9x50 and I'm REALLY loving this outfit.

I've made mention on the forums that I'm concerned that there is no score rewards based on target range despite the obvious (monetary) push to high-quality equipment. In my view this is wrong
column18:
both ingame and economically. My weapons and equipment need to be valuable to me but there is no reason to use anything other than a 12 gauge with the right ammo for the kill. Why charge up to $15 RL money for a gun and scope that counts towards.... nothing?

-Animal Tracking
I like the way this has been done. It's very difficult to mimic the senses from a 3D enviroment in a 2D rectangle and yet this gives a sense of tracking success with target sighting as the eventual reward. The kill itself does become secondary on the harder to track species and I've once or twice found myself shooting only a photo and simply walking away. Seriously.

-Competitions
Good fun and ultimately (at least for me) is the reason I play. Nope
column19:
I haven't won any as I write but I've got close. The planning and dedication required to win a trophy is high level stuff and really needs to be worked at. I'm loving them. Soon.......

- GENERAL -
In the interests of brevity I'm going to mention the words achievements (LOTS of them)

column25:
evaluate your UI on your grandmothers. If they're confused it's bad OK?  Even ingame I find some "habit formed clicking" breaks on some changes to equipment.

..oo00oo..

- SUMMARY -

CONS
Tedious at times with all that walking.
Could ultimately cost quite a bit.
UI.
Scoring is errr.... pointless. (pun intended)

As an Aussie

If you're an RL hunter but can't get out enough. GET THIS. No question.

reviewText:
Love this game, the only reason so m any people hate it is because it says free to play and it isn't. I would urge the makers of the game to remove its free to play status and just be honest. It is limited for free to play and it's mostly a pay to play game. With that being said, I'll continue with why I love the game.

It is an EXCELLENT pay to play game and literally the only online game I have subscribed to aside from World Of Warcraft when I was younger. Me, my buddy and my girlfreind spend hours at a time stalking and killing Elk with the amazing tracking system and the detailed injury system, allowing you to see exactly what organs you've hit on the animal after you collect the kill. This helps you to make a more precise and fast kill the next time, eventually leading you from shooting wildly at the animal and tracking it forever, to shooting the animal exactly where it's vital organs are, killing it in one swift killshot. This get's even better when you use weapons that are silent like bows or crossbows, enabling you to kil animals quick and silently without alerting others in the heard they are travelling with. I've taken doiwn 4 or 5 animals in one silent swipe with my buddy before, making tandem kills and picking the off animals lagging behind the rest of the heard.

I also enjoy that there are many different ways to earn the in game real money currency em$". Aside from spending your cash on it

reviewText:
So here we are again, out in the wilderness, days gone by and your hard, throbbing member has yet to be planted into some raw, juicy rear.
You sit out in your scrawny little watch tower when suddenly--
Bluargh!
That's it, all you've been waiting for, that one handsome and musculant call from the woods.
You take out your Deer Homo Caller™ and let out one equally as homoerotic call, hoping that it'll react to it. You patiently wait out those painstaking minutes which feel like hours.
You look through your binoculars and you see something, something in the bush, that isn't quite right.

It's the antlers, those big, pointy and majestic antlers, piercing through the foilage,
Your nerves are going haywire, your breathing is out of control, but you manage to keep your binoculars steady, as you focus on the beast.
It breaks through the foilage, there is is, muscular, sweaty and musky stag just waiting to be plugged.

You stow your binoculars away as you approach the galiant beast, every step you take towards it makes your heart beat faster and faster, you can see it, you can smell it, you can feel it.

And there it is, right in front of you, just a stone toss away, you're ready, you've prepared your whole life for this, your senses are going through the roof.
You reach into your pants, unbuckle the strap, whop out your throbbing and well-greased 'gun'.
You clear your mind, slow down your breathing, and take aim.

BANG!

Everything quiets down, there you are, right on top of it, you stroke your hand over the fur and gently carass the antlers.
After filling it up with your munition, and just as you're about to pull out, a mysterious man walks out of the woods and looks you straight in the eyes.

It has come to my attention that you've been dropping Whitetail Deer with unpermitted ammo."
To hell with you

reviewText:
I recommend The Hunter for anyone that has ever wondered how hunting really is. It's a free game that allows people to hunt Whitetail Deer, pheasant, and all types of rabbits. The graphics and realism of the animal's detection system is as realistic as hunting can be. Hunting is a game of patience & stealth and always has been - elements that are accurately instilled into this game. Don't anticipate collateral noscope headshots playing this.
~Pros~
-Amazing Graphics & incredible terrain with 60-80 fps
-Diverse hunting terrains from swamps to dense forests to the arctic circle
-Great AI and animations that replicates animal's mannerisms in real life
-Very realistic ambient sound effects that are unique to each map
-Surround sound footsteps, calls, & noises help narrow down your prey's location
-Play with friends (for free!)
-9 of 10 maps have something huntable for free accounts
-Realistic Ballistics
-Licenses to hunt other animals can be acquired from completing missions

~Cons~
-(Biggest)You need to pay a monthly subscription for licenses to hunt any other type of animal
-No lump sum payment to just buy the game for all of its content - you must pay monthly.

I have only played the free version of this game and still enjoy it everytime. It is a very relaxing experience that grows in intensity once you're stalking your prey. Once you get your first kill, you'll want to come back for more.

Give it a try, after all, it is free!

---------------------------------------------------UPDATE------------------------------------------

Recently purchased the 12 month Trailrunner subscription ($50) and I could not be happier! They give you 8 guns & an awesome bow, excellent camo clothing, callers, 3 deployable towers, a tree stand, wind indicator, a tent along with licenses to hunt every animal & host your own server.

I absolutely love the stealth aspect that comes with stalking your prey. Using the bow is even more challenging since you need to get very close to your animal to get the best shot. Never thought I'd enjoy the bow better than guns, but when you can silently take out a flock of turkeys/deer/elk etc. it is very fun.

I'll continue to revise this review as time goes on.

reviewText:
I am a long time player and will try to make this review informative and realistic.

*** Gameplay
I tried this game and liked it so much that I purchased a one-year membership after a few days. The relaxed and realistic atmosphere is likely one of the biggest sellers for the game. You basically roam the woods looking for animals, or clues that can lead you to them. There are a lot more animals in the game than what you would see in real life. Also the animals are less shy than in nature, so that you will find plenty of them even in a short hunting session. You will discover traces on the ground or hear animals call somewhere in the distance. Once an animal is tracked down, you may opt for a kill or move on. Tracking gets easier the more you play. With the increasing number of tracks that you pick up, your skill level rises and tracking becomes easier. It also happens a lot that you see single animals or a group of them roaming around as you walk through the reserves. This game is not for someone trying to get satisfaction in a lot of animal shooting in a short time.

*** Memberships
All players start as guest" and receives a free rifle and life-long free ammunition for this gun and some basic equipment. A membership is a time-limited license that will unlock all animals
recommended:
and also the ability to host multiplayer parties. A permanent license is not available.

*** Hunting Grounds
The reserves in the western part of this world resemble of American continent-based areas
hoursPlayed:
the eastern part holds areas that you could easily find in Europe. Currently seven reserves are available. Each has its own charm and of course its animal species. At the beginning of every hunt you select a reserve. You can start from a permanent lodge or from a tent that you have placed in the reserve before. The maps are very big and if needed there is a fast travelling system.

*** Animals
At this point the game features 18 species. Some of them can attack the player. Many can be lured with callers
voteText: scents or decoys. Then there are baiting stations that will bring the animals to a certain location. Most bird species are only scored if shot in the air
helpfulPercent: which is always a fun challenge. For many species unusual fur variations can be found
votesHelpful: some of which are truly rare. Shooting such a rare animal is just as special as a trophy buck. Shooting animals in theHunter quite demanding. The animals have bones and organs
votesTotal: and every shot should be thought through before the trigger is pulled. Hitting vital organs will lead to death
votesFunny:
bad shots can result in a follow-up search.

*** Weapons
A host of rifles is available
commentsCount: all of which can be equipped with scopes for longer shots. Using the open sights can be just as much fun though. Depending on the knock-down capabilities of these guns they are allowed to be used for larger or smaller game. There is also a selection of handguns
column16: some with plenty of power to even kill a moose. Shotguns can be used with three types of ammunition
column17:
which makes them all-around weapons for all animals.
Shooting guns makes all animals in the area flee. Bows can be used as silent killers and will not alarm other animals unless they are really close.

*** Equipment
There is equipment that can be permanently placed in the reserves. Tents let you to start a hunt where ever you placed them before
column18: and they give you access to your entire inventory just like a lodge. There are treestands that can be mounted to trees for a better overview of the area. Ground and waterfowl blinds protect you on the ground from being seen
column19:
and a tripod stand provides some elevation for easier animal spotting.

*** In-game Money
All game items are paid with the in-game currency em$. It can be purchased with real money
column20: won in competitions
column21: or earned by completing third-party offers. Also there are gm$ that can be earned by completing missions
column22: allowing to buy consumables. Non-consumable items belong to the player permanently
column23:
even if a membership expires.

*** Missions
Currently there are a total of 245 missions available. Most mission packs start rather easy and become increasingly more difficult. You will end up shooting pheasants or geese in air with bows
column24:
or try to make a moose attack you for an adrenaline kill.

*** Competitions & Leaderboards
Competitions are run around the clock for all animals. Players from around the world sign up and compete against each other. The top players receive a trophy which appears on the player's profile. In addition em$ can be earned. All animals of all players are compared during every season and represented on leaderboards. The best players will make their way into the Hall of Fame.

*** Multiplayer
Multiplayer parties are client-based
column25: there are no MP servers. In the game it is possible to chat with others. Players can hunt as team or on their own. It is advisable that people from the same geographical regions connect for such games
column26:
or there can be lagging.

*** Things I don't like
- The website's style is not "outdoor-like". Also the font size and the line spacing are too large. There is a lot of scrolling to be done when going through statistics or the store.
- The large antlers of the Red Deer are completely unrealistic. The red deer in the game does not look like the real one
column27: and that is a real pity for me
column28: being European.\n- Some animals have too large eyes and thus look like large baby animals. The most obvious ones are the Brown Bear and the Roe Deer.\n- It is not possible to jump or climb over the smallest obstacles and you have to circumvent them.  Sometimes it would be handy to climb a rock and gain a bit better overview
column29:
but many rocks cannot be climbed.

*** Conclusion
The game is constantly being enhanced with new content. It remains one of the best games I have ever played
column30: and certainly played for the longest time. Playing long nights is not tiring even if it gets really busy around you at times. It is unique with its  lively environment and ambient sounds
column31: but can be just as much challenging when trying to pin down the trophy animal. There is a great random factor and unpredictability
column32: which I think among many other things is the greatest achievement of the developers. I keep playing because every game session can be so much different to the former
column33: and so the game just never gets old.\n"

reviewText:
I'll make this quick,

This game is a ton of fun espically if you're a hunter in real life, there's a lot of negative comments here too about how this game isn't free and it's posing as one (last I checked).  It is free indeed, you can hunt three or four animals as a guest and those animals are as followed.

Whitetail

Cottontail rabbit

Pheasant.

There's also special events that go on that allows you to hunt certain animals for a certain ammount of time for free, however. If you wish to invest in the game, it's actually a fair deal and they're not asking for a a lot either. 500 ems is worth 4.99 USD and 3 months of memberhip is around 10$ USD, there's obviously other options but those are the two cheapest and it's quite fair if you ask me.

Overall, I really enjoy this game, it's a lot of fun getting to hunt the animals in the map locations, plus it's really good for time consumption as well. After all, I play this game when I do my homework while sitting in a tree stand or hunting tower lol.

Either way to sum things up, don't judge this game by the negative reviews until you actually tried it yourself, you may or may not like it and this is as close as hunting I can get when the season for whitetail irl isn't opened.

So overall, if you're a fellow real life hunter as myself here, you'll enjoy the game!

reviewText:
DO NOT BELIEVE ALL THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS...THIS IS A GREAT HUNTING GAME!

Q. Is it TOTALLY FREE to Play?
A. Yes & No. This game has enough to play for free if, (A) you are just a casual hunter playing now and again,
(B) you don't mind only hunting 5 types of anaimals (Whitetail Deer, Cottontail & European Rabbits, Snowshoe Hare, Pheasant),
(C) you play to earn gm$ (in game money) by doing missions, then spend that on other game licenses.

Q. Do I HAVE TO SPEND A LOT of Real Money to play?
A. No not at all. If you want to hunt all the animals you can get a subscription that only cost $3.33 a month (less if you get a longer sub)
If you want to own a lot of weapons, clothing, hunting dog, etc. to customise your character you'll have to spend some real money to get em$ (the in game money that you buy with real money) but how much is up to you.
*If you buy one of the DLC" those are the subscriptions (3
recommended: they cost slightly more then normal subscriptions
hoursPlayed: BUT you only by those once for the bonus items then resub at normal rate. The bonus items are worth the extra as it will save you money over buying them separately.\n\nAs a FREE Player you can hunt the 5 animals I mentioned above
voteText:
you can track and spot any animal in the game.
You start with 2 free weapons (.243 Bolt Action Rifle and the Single Shot Shotgun).
You can hunt on anywhere on the map (some areas will have nothing to shoot for free players).
You can hunt with you friends in multiplayer...No You Can Not Shoot Your Friends No Matter How Much You Would Like To!

Q. Can you walk for long periods of time and not spot anything?
A. Yes

reviewText:
Hello All Hunters

I been playing this game before it even came to steam. I been on it for almost 3 years I believe. I really enjoy this game since this is the closest I can come to being a hunter without buying a hunting license, a gun and ammo, and a lease. I find the graphics to be pretty detailed and all the ambient sound makes it feel like I'm actually in the wild. As a F2P (a term everyone hates) shooter, its fun and relaxing at the same time. The game isn't perfect by no means with some AI bugs, pop ups, limited draw distance, and other hic-ups. But everyone grips about hunting only mule deer and having 1 rifle and deer calls. You have to buy a license to hunt other animals in the game that roam around in the same world. They grip about license expiring after certain set times. People forget that this is cheaper than going out and buying real life guns, ammo, leases, and a hunting license thats good for 1 year. Enough of my short rant. Only thing I don't like about the game is that to get em$, you have to ether buy it or do third party surveys, apps, videos, or other stuff they want you to do for the em$. The missions are a nice touch but only reward you with gm$ which you use to buy different ammo. And to buy extra guns, stands, and other calls you'll need em$ which is hard to come by. Other then those grips the game is a pretty run and relaxing hunting trip thats so much better than a Cabela's hunting game any day.

Multiplayer - Basicly if you are a guest (F2P) you can't host any multiplayer game but you can join but due to the restriction of the guest, you can only hunt on Logger's Point. But members can host any game and set any restriction on who can join.

reviewText: It is best to think of TheHunter as a full-priced game in which you have to invest atleast 50 euro's: a pathfinder-membership for half a year and an additional twenty euro's for buying some necessary gear which will make hunting a lot easier. This investment is only worth it, if you enjoy a slow-paced realistic hunting game with hours of walking around, tracking and preparing. That is not to say that it will take you hours to make your first kill. With some due dilligence, a quarter of an hour is enough to encounter a deer that walks past your sights and gives you the opportunity to collect your first trophy. And that's what makes this game not only good, but at times even masterful. The satisfaction of landing a kill is immense if you spent a lot of work preparing for the perfect shot. If all this appeals to you, TheHunter is a great game. It is beautiful, immersive, dense, packed with wildlife and loads of equipment and weapons to explore; that is, provided you pay for them...

reviewText: My friend and I one night were looking for something to play together and goof off in. that's when I stumbled across this game. After about 10 min. of struggling with trying to get in the same game we found that when we both joined there was nobody else in the game.
