reviewText:
This one is great for when you just want to slow things down, take your time, and slaughter innocent forest creatures. Unfortunately these game devs have a horrible reputation for greed and poor customer service. They boast that it is they most realistic hunting game out there... and that's not quite true..

While the terrain and landscapes are very well done; the draw distance is very limited in this game which is EXACTLY what a hunting game shouldn't have. The animals (excluding the deer) in the game are very poorly detailed, both aesthetically, as well as their movements.

The game engine and graphics are VERY dated. If you've ever hunted in Assassin's Creed 3 or Far Cry: Primal you probably found the animals looked much better, and moved much better. The weapon handling smoother. Not to mention the baiting and trapping you can do in those.

Then there's the business model. Not only are you required to subscribe or purchase liscences (with REAL money) in order to hunt the different animals in different locations, but its also riddled with a boatload of microtransactions for guns, ammo, nests, blinds, and pretty much EVERYTHING the game has to offer. Basically its a wring out every dollar greed fest.

Only spend money on this game if their packages on steam are at a MAJOR discount.

reviewText: The business model on this game is literally a complete rip off. Don't get me wrong, I'm not always against pay to play games. But, when you pay for a monthly membership on this game, you literally get no decent updates at all. They never come out with anything new or groundbreaking. They always just release new store items and gimmicks to try and siphon more funds from you.  That's right, once you are already a paying member they still try to extract more money from you without giving you the content you are already paying for.  It's a shame really. Hopefully another company will come out with a decent hunting game.

reviewText:
Addictive Gaming Experience
About Me:  I only show to have a few hours into the game since it recently released to Steam, but have played since release & have over 1500 total played hours over the years.  I enjoy both Hunting & Gaming, so finding & playing the best hunting game comes natural to me.

TheHunter:  First things first...this is not a shoot-em'-up game where you sprint through the woods guns-a-blazin'.  You will often be crouching through the woods or sitting in a stand, if that's your preference.  Some will see this game style as a bit slow or even boring at times, especially if they're used to playing a FPS.  That being said, theHunter is a good compromise between Hunting Simulation & video game.

Strengths

Variety:  There are currently 18 different species that you can hunt in theHunter, and that number continues to grow as they add new content.  There are the small deer species (roe, blacktail, whitetail, mule deer), larger deer species (roosevelt elk, moose, red deer), waterfowl (mallards & Canadian geese), canines (fox & coyote), hogs (wild boar & feral hogs), bear (black & brown), birds (pheasant & turkey), and small game (rabbits).  There are also 7 different maps for you to hunt these animals, containing anywhere from 4 to 6 different species in each map.  You also have access to 32 different weapons with which to choose from, which allows you to hunt with a variety of rifles, pistols, primitive bows, compound bows, shotguns, a flintlock muzzleloader, or even an air rifle, each with different scopes for you to use.  Further adding to the variety offered in theHunter are the different types of camo & large equipment, such as treestands, blinds, feeders, bear bait barrels, etc.

Replayability:    When you start a new game in theHunter, the animals are randomly generated on the map.  This only happens once, which is right when the game starts.  There are no “respawns” as you harvest animals throughout the course of your game.  Nobody knows exactly how this works, but suffice to say that you have close to an equal number of each species on the map that you selected.  There will always be animals that are trophy worthy, and it is up to you to use your skill & patience to find them.  Along with the trophy animals are rare variations of almost every species offered.  This gives you a real sense of accomplishment when you find an albino bull elk, that trophy piebald whitetail, or the rarest of rare bears.  All of the deer species use a system called TruRacs that generates the antlers that you see in-game, and it is different every time.  All of these things, combined with the variety above, give this game a great amount of addictive replayability.  In one hunt, you might be shooting for a red deer muzzleloading competition in Hirschfelden wearing the trapper outfit & in the next you might be hunting mallard ducks in the swamps of the Rougarou Bayou online with your friends.  Even if you start in the same location & hunt the same species repeatedly, no two animals you kill will be identical & no two hunts will be the same.

Adding to the replayability in theHunter are Competitions, Missions, Achievements, & Skills.  There is at least one Competition available every day for each species, most often lasting a day or two each.  There are also 250 different Missions available.  These are optional, but now earn you a currency called gm$, which can be spent on some consumable items, such as scent eliminator spray.  You can also increase your Hunter score by earning Achievements, which are mostly earned through killing x number of species or x number of kills with each weapon.  You also increase your skills along the way, making you better at tracking & spotting game.  An expert tracker can tell the sex of the animal, along with good estimates of the track’s age & the weight of the animal, while an expert spotter can give you a really good estimate of the animal’s score.

Developer/Community:  This is easily the best gaming community that I have ever had the pleasure of playing & communicating with.  The developers are actively involved in the Forums, and allow the community to make suggestions for future content.  They send out surveys regularly & then deliver the content that the community wants.  The community also hosts their own competitions that pay out significantly more than the official ones.

Special Events:  theHunter throws out some pretty cool special events for certain holidays.  Sometimes, it’s just a special item (see Xmas beanie or St Patty’s Day hat) but sometimes it can be weeks’ long competitions that award guns or special trophies that are only awarded during that time.

Graphics:  All in all, the game is absolutely beautiful, with nice water & weather effects.  Inside 200m the game is breathtaking.  The graphics do show their weakness if you’re zooming in with binoculars or a scope beyond 250m or so.  That is an engine issue, which I will talk about below.

Weaknesses:

Dated Game Engine:  The biggest weakness in theHunter is it’s dated game engine.  Specifically, the draw range of animals & most objects is limited to somewhere around 250m.  While the game boasts realistic ballistics & has beautiful scenery, that immersion is broken when you reach the summit of a mountain in Hammerfel and can’t spot animals on the opposite mountain.  You see, due to the limited nature of the engine, the game doesn’t draw those animals.  They exist, but you can’t see them until they come inside that 250m range.

Cost:  I personally don’t agree with this being a weakness, but I’ve been around theHunter long enough to know that most do view this as an area of concern.  First, let me say that the “Free to Play” is extremely limiting, and it should be.  I wish they wouldn’t even market it this way, as it gives people the wrong impression from the outset.  The bottom line is the game offers you a ton of content, much of which is not necessary, but costs money.  You can hunt every species in the game with the basic single shot shotgun that can be purchased with your gm$ earned through Missions, you can spend a little extra for gold engraved shotguns & rifles, or you can land somewhere in between.

Purchasing the Trailrunner membership is easily the best bet for the new player, giving you all you need to hunt every species on every map for a year for $43.99, and is my advice for anybody that is just starting out.  If you still want to play after that year has expired, then in my opinion, it’s well worth the money to extend your membership.

OVERALL:
theHunter is an addictive blend of hunting simulation & gaming, offering high replayability through randomly generated animals, enormous maps, variety in hunting methods & species.  You always have a carrot to chase, whether it’s finding that next trophy animal, looking for rare variations, trying to win competitions, reach the leaderboards & hall of fame, or completing achievements, missions, and increasing your skills.  If you can afford the Trailrunner ($43.99) membership and don’t mind the slower playstyle of a hunting simulation, then I wouldn’t hesitate to pick this game up.

reviewText: A game that may have been state of the art ten years ago, 99% of content locked away behind very restrictive paywalls. Want to shoot some other kind of deer? 10 bucks. Want to shoot a rabbit? Sorry your starter rifle isn't permitted, how about a shotgun with birdshot for 5 bucks? There is an ingame currency that you can earn doing missions" but that is only usable to buy limited use lures and ammunition. Weapons? Real money. Clothing? Bags? Scopes? Your credit card please. And it's not just nickel and dime stuff
date:
weapons are 5-10 a pop and scopes start around 4.

One of the few developers that hasn't figured out how to do a proper f2p model in tyool 2014. If the game didn't nag and badger you to fork over your money every five minutes and let you actually do and earn currency it would be a whole lot better and attract more customers.

But before you go

reviewText:
Here's how it basically works:


-Each animal needs a license to be hunted. You can't have permanent licenses. You can buy membership to have all licenses for 3 - 6 - 12 months.
-You can hunt animals only with the right rifles, meaning if you buy the license for Bear hunting but you don't have a weapon that's good for it then you can't hunt it.
-F2P = license to hunt Mule Deer and Rabbit, 1 weapon with which you can hunt Mule Deer but not Rabbit. Unlimited ammo for that weapon, a scope and a Mule Deer caller" ( idk how to call it i'm not native english )
-You need to buy ammos for weapons. Meaning if you buy a shotgun then you need to buy it's ammos. When you finish the ammos ( 2 euros are usually 10-20 ammos  depends on the ammo type ) then you need to buy other ammos.
-Every rifle costs from 5 to 20 euros.
-Clothes

and all that ♥♥♥♥ that helps you have a easier hunt cost real money.

reviewText:
I'm a long time player whit multiple accounts.

This review is not about the game itself (which is great). It's about EW business model and how they are greedy.

Some companies choose to sell a full game at a full price and then charge for DLCs (Guns, equipment, cloth bundles etc…) separately. Other companies prefer to make monthly subscription system; you will pay monthly to have access to a full content game. Both are okay. However, some greedy companies like EW choose to do both at the same time whit the same game. Of course, nobody is forcing you to pay, but you will have a limited experience even subscribing monthly. You subscribe monthly and then you need to pay for every single piece of equipment you want, if you want to have a full experience. It isn’t monthly subscription enough? If you can pay for it, it is okay. Or if you content yourself by subscribing and playing whit only 2 or 3 guns whit no cool equipment. It's a game for rich people. A money Wormhole.

They want your last cents. Don't be fooled by fanboys and their stupid arguments about F2P" and how this game is "cheap"."

reviewText:
What is theHunter?
The best hunting game on the market! Or in other words: a stealth fps in a rl setting. The 10 maps range from arctic to arid climate. You can hunt 30 different animals form bisons to ducks and rabbits. You can use over 50 different weapons (rifles, handguns, shotguns, bows / crossbows and muzzleloaders). There´s a lot of equipment like different clothing, lures, callers, feeders, tree-stands and even dogs at your disposal.
It´s entirely up to you what you want to do and how you want to play. You can just hunt for fun - or watch animals and enjoy the scenery. You can hunt together with others (as host or on your friends maps). You can try to improve your hunterscore to impress fellow hunters (by hunting a lot of animals with different weapons). You can join competitions and try to win some trophies (or even in game money). You can join various events like christmas hunts ... or do the missions and earn some ingame money that way.
Is it a free game?
Yes! No! ... ;)  The most negative reviews are related to that question and the pay system. Here are the facts: You can download the game and play it for free. You´ll be playing as a guest. Guests have limited rights. You´ll get one rifle and a shotgun. You have a guest-license to hunt rabbits, pheasants and whitetail deer. All other animals are off limits. When you try to shoot them you´ll get a message you need a license for that" and your rifle is blocked for that shot.
Pay to win?
No! Yes! ... ;) The answer depends completely on the "win-condition". If you join a competition "highest-scoring whitetail deer" as a guest you could easily win it without any further equipment. The limiting factor is you game-time and luck. If you look at other competitions like "most turkey in 24h" you might have to invest in special equipment in order to win. But since all competitors will use the same equipment there´s no way to buy a win in that competition either. Non-equipped players are just factically excluded from the trophies. If you want to play in an ice-hockey league in rl
date: you´d have to buy the equipment. Would you call that pay to win? I think "pay to participate in some activities" would be more correct."

reviewText:
Some facts first:
I am playing TheHunter for almost 5 years now.
Spent about 150 EUR.
Still enjoying the game because of the updates and
good cooperation of devs and community.

Yes - I recommend this game.
It is a special genre for patient players.
For beginners it´s recommended to read the Wiki/forums first and
play some tutorials perhaps.

I really like the atmosphere in the reserves - there are a lot in the meantime.
From spring to winter - from rabbits to bisons...you can play through a lot of
different missions which gives you Gamedollars" as reward to buy consumables
which are pretty helpful in the game.

The recent update (Jan 27th 2016) allows guests (F2P) to hunt more than one species now
and hunt them in different reserves. Just a result of the good coworking of the community and the devs of EW.

If you want to visit my profile follow this link: http://www.thehunter.com/#profile/hardtree/"

reviewText:
So I got together with a couple of mates a couple days ago and we played this game for like 8 hours. I'll give you my opinion of the game.

Textures - 7/10
Textures are reasonable for an open-world game, but could be better.

Scripting/Execution/AI - 7/10
I'll give it descent credit because the AI is kind of detailed, but does glitch occasionally.

3D Models & Art - 8/10
The 3D modellers for this game put a lot of work into the models, which I appreciate as a game developer myself.

Gameplay - ?/10
Your opinion on this game's gameplay is very dependant on your playing style and your style of game. If you play games like Call of Duty or Team Fortress than you probably won't enjoy it all that much, but if you prefer slower-paced games like Minecraft, 7 Days to Die, or like Farming Simulator, you probably will enjoy it lots. But that's just my interpretation. On another note, this game can also be incredibly boring. You could be tracking an animal for three hours and only find their feces. But that's where the slower-paced gamers come into play. If you like to play games with your friends, than I HIGHLY recommend grabbing a couple of friends and getting into a game together. It gets a lot better if you have some friends with you.

Features - 0.5/10
If you've played this game before reading this review than you probably know what I'm talking about. The per month fee that you have to pay to play this game is rediculous. Sure, the game is labeled as free, but in reality all you get is a really, REALLY limited demo of the game. In this demo you get to explore about 5% of the games full map, get one weapon, and you can only hunt a small number of animals. Like one or two. Once you think about it, you end up paying like WAY more for this free" game than any other game if you are going to play it long-term. It's $15.99 for three months of minimum game features. You can pay more for some more weapons and gear
date: and EVEN more for what should've been offered with the original copy of the game. And even if you don't want to get into this game long term
recommended:
you can pay more actual money for face-camos and things like that and you only get about 10 uses for $0.99.

Overall - 2.25/10
This game could have been incredibly succesfull and entertaining if there wasn't some scam of a fee. I understand that they want to make money for their work
hoursPlayed: but it would have been a better idea to charge maybe $10.00 or $15.00 for the full game. If you like slower-paced games and you wanted to pay $15.00 for 3 months of partial features
voteText: or nothing at all for a demo. I do not recommend this game to anybody unless you have a few friends that are willing to pay the fee as well as you."

reviewText:
An absolutely emotional rollercoaster of action and suspense, this game managed to completely envelop me in its world as I fumbled with the awful controls. Once realizing my top running speed was 1.5 MPH, I was off to hunt my first deer. The journey was tough, as I crawled along, finding tracks for numerous rabbits, but no deer. Finally I was on the trail. Days and nights passed as I embarked on a quest to trudge through a forest, spamming the deer call. Finally, I was answered. A deer bleat echoed off the trees to my left, signaling that something had recieved my call. I readied my rifle, prepared for whatever awaited me past the trunks of the nearby forest. There, it stood. A beautiful, majestic mule deer waited in the pasture, looking for the source of the familiar call. I quickly tried to aim, but alas! It took off! However, this is no normal hunter you're dealing with. A well placed shot quickly dropped the animal to the ground, and I ran over to see my kill.

Unfortunately harvesting the deer crashed my game.

Also this game blows, seriously don't play it. If you've ever wanted to know what it's like to hunt deer as Steven Hawking, this is your game.
voteText: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is the most realistic hunting game you could ever ask for. As an avid hunter, I find it exciting to explore new places and hunt different animals that I may never have the chance to in real life.

On the downside, it is very expensive to hunt different animals. Ducks for example, you need to buy a shotgun, ammo, camoflauge, decoys, calls, blinds, and a dog to be efficient at hunting them. This could add up to hundreds of real dollars. It would be nice if they would make it possible to make in-game currency through certain tasks where you could buy all of the items with it. They do have an in game-currency, but you can only buy consumables with it and it is difficult to aquire.

overall, 8/10

reviewText:
There has been a lot of nonsense written about the Hunter so hopefully I@ll try and clear up what causes the negatives in this review.

First off playing for free, I played for free for a couple of weeks, 5 species to hunt and access to all reserves (each of which is absolutely stunning). It's not so so much free to play as it is a demo tbh but a good enough demo to get me hooked.

Costs involved are pretty minimal. With a memberships (about £3 or £4) a month you are allowed to hunt any animal and between the free rifle and free shotgun you have the capability to kill anything in the game except Bison which would require buying a more powerful weapon.

A lot of the negative reviews are all moaning about licences but hey lets face facts here if these guys can't afford  less than a pound per week for membership then they have bigger things to worry about than computer games tbh.

On to the actual game,

Pros
+Great feeling of being out in the wild and each reserve is styled on real world hunting locations,
+Animal behaviour is well modelled
+loads of missions to and competitions running every day in which you can earn ingame currency. (Free players can enter comps too)
+The RPG elements of your skills works really well as you increase your spotting, tracking and shooting skill you get real benefits from the not just higher numbers on a stats page.
+Really nice and helpful community especially on the official forums.

So what are you waiting for?, get started hunting now and keep in your mind that's it's free to try but to get a fuller game experience you will need a membership costing a few quid (£3-£4) a month.

reviewText: OK...heres the real story. YES...you need a membership to hunt all animals, but you can try the game for free  and hunt muledeer, with a rifle they give you for free. If you like the game then fine, you can order a 3,6 or yearly memberships, and its fairely cheep. The bigger the memberhsip you order the more free stuff you get. I ordered a 6 month membership and got everything I think I'd need to play forever, in guns anyways. If you have to collect everythign ingame yes it gets expensive but why do it? A shotgun can hunt anything...ANYTHING IN GAME ...because it has 3 kinds of ammo.\n\nthere are fancy guns with ingraving for people who need those, but never for free..doh....and several types of bows and arrows and sights scopes, etc and on and on...but you don't need all that. For less than the cost of lottery tickets you can play all year long, and hunt every animal you ever wanted in  great detailed forests and on cold snowly mountains. No...its not all free, but trying it out is, so try it or leave it, no problem...but its a good game, just not what many people hoped for.

reviewText: theHunter is definitely my new addiction. The graphics are just purely amazing and also the gameplay is really well done. reviewText:
The best hunting game around.
Some people feel cheated when they discover it is not ENTIRELY free to play, but the demo is.
Believe me: buying a membership is worth every penny.
You can spend hours roaming the big forests and meadows, while all different wildlife surrounds you.
While every species (or group of species) needs a different approach, there is a lot to discover.
Great graphics, and thebest part: the game evolves.
Australia coming up, and much more I believe.
Big thumbs up from me.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Lets talk anout the pay to win....

In order to hunt anything other than Mule deer and Rabbit(non-members dont get a shotgun for rabbit) you need a membership or a specific licence.

I don't entirely agree with this system, it causes you to have to pay a lot of real money over time as opposed to just paying money for the game and being able to get all the in-game stuff without real money.

All of this aside, the gameplay is amazing, it strikes a good balence between simulation/realism and enjoyment.
Most animals are not so hard that you get extremely bored (as long as you're hunting correctly) yet some of them can be tricky to hunt. They each have they're own habitat,(some are in more than one reserve)sounds, difficulty, and weapons that you can use for them.(don't worry about having to buy a ton of guns for all of the animals)

Overall, if you can put up with the payment system, and you have some patience. This game is extremely fun to play.

reviewText: The game in itself is ok. The character is really slow tho! He takes forever to aim the weapons, very unrealisticly so to! But over all the actual game is good enough. However it is REALLY expencive! You have to pay a subscription that is way to expencive for this game, AND you have to pay for nearly every in-game item, from weapons, clothes to ammunition, They advertise that there is an in-game currency, but this is almost worthless, you can't by mutch with it, and you don't get mutch of it either. If you want to unlock new stuff, you have to pay real money. Playing this game for a year is only slightly less expencive than hunting IRL. And I can't emphazise how slow the character is! The running/walking thing is ok, but the aiming, sighting, and operating of the weapons are so increadible slow! I've seen people that never fired a weapon before do it twice as fast. reviewText: I'm going to start off by saying this game has a lot of potential to be an amazing hunting simulator. The fact that is multiplayer is also a fun bonus. The false advertising rubbed me in all the wrong ways however; this game is not free to play (unless you like a hiking simulator dressed up as a hunting simulator). To actually hunt in this game you have to spend real money on licenses, guns, etc. I'm hoping in the future that this game will actually allow you to hunt a bit more without spending money (or just costing money right off the bat). This game does have a lot of promise but right now I wouldn't waste your time downloading it.

reviewText:
The best hunting game around.
Some people feel cheated when they discover it is not ENTIRELY free to play, but the demo is.
Believe me: buying a membership is worth every penny.
You can spend hours roaming the big forests and meadows, while all different wildlife surrounds you.
While every species (or group of species) needs a different approach, there is a lot to discover.
Great graphics, and thebest part: the game evolves.
Australia coming up, and much more I believe.
Big thumbs up from me.

reviewText:
Lets talk anout the pay to win....

In order to hunt anything other than Mule deer and Rabbit(non-members dont get a shotgun for rabbit) you need a membership or a specific licence.

I don't entirely agree with this system, it causes you to have to pay a lot of real money over time as opposed to just paying money for the game and being able to get all the in-game stuff without real money.

All of this aside, the gameplay is amazing, it strikes a good balence between simulation/realism and enjoyment.
Most animals are not so hard that you get extremely bored (as long as you're hunting correctly) yet some of them can be tricky to hunt. They each have they're own habitat,(some are in more than one reserve)sounds, difficulty, and weapons that you can use for them.(don't worry about having to buy a ton of guns for all of the animals)

Overall, if you can put up with the payment system, and you have some patience. This game is extremely fun to play.

reviewText: A huge let down. EVERYTHING is locked behind microtransactions, good luck shooting anything that you actually have a liscense for let alone ANYTHING AT ALL! Lots of unpolished, wonky stuff like tracking, Your character sprints like they have polio and about as fast, aiming is borderline impossible since your character can't hold his gun still to save his life. I hunt in real life with a compound bow, and I can tell you right now that it is WAAAAAAAY easier in real life. Go buy a hunting license and hunt real animals. You'd be surprised how much fun it really is.

reviewText:
The gameplay is amazing. I really dig it. Walking trough the woods. with a pair of buddies. tracking an animal together. listening to animals calls trying to find the one you're looking for. But. Theres a big but.

The buissness model is simly awful. this should not be in the free to play section. but in a new section called Free to Pay. As the game will try to squeeze every penny it can out of you. What you do get for free. is a low caliber bolt action hunting rifle. With unlimited ammunition. a pair of binoculars. and a little bit of camping supplies for fast travel (consumables) The game features two currencys. Quite usual for the Free to play market. Yet also has a subscription! And one does not grant you the olther! Subscription or Membership" Will grant you a "License" To hunt all animals. But the rifle you start with is not "Ethical" for all of them. thus you will have to spend even more money to actually take part in competitons. or get score for theese animals

EM$: A currency used to get absolutly everything the ratio is 100 EM$ = Dollar. But the smallest package you can buy is 500. for 5 dollars. the larger packages save you a little bit of cash. EM$ Is the currency used to buy about anything. Clothing. weapons and so on. Yet a single item will cost you 3-7 dollars. For just a single item. "Happy Camper tents" Will cost you 550 EM. But there is no 550 Package. Forcing you to spend more money!

While there are competitions in game with EM Prizes. To get to them. you will most likely have to spend money. Again!

GM$: An in game currency. You might think that you get GM from hunting animals. And you'd be wrong. All you get is score. in a phatetic attempt to squeeze more money out of you. GM is earned by compleating missions. theese have a finite number. and most of them require you to use a peticular weapon or hunt an animal you will not have acsess too. without opening your wallet up.

And do not ague that the microtransaction system lets you have "Choice" As it does not. The design of the game. maps. liceances. all of that is under the influance to squeeze more MONEY out of you wallet. And it will not stop untill you have everything. And once you do. They will still try and squeeze money out of you on a monthly basis.

EIther have microtransactions. or a subscription. having both is disgusting.
"

reviewText: I've been playing the free version since 2009 when my PC could barely run it. Now I've got a much beefier PC and decided to take the plunge and buy a membership. $54(CAD) for the Trailrunner starter pack (Best deal IMO) gives you a very nice selection of weapons/equipment, and all licenses for a year.\n\nAll I can say is wow. I'm not dissappointed at all with my purchase. I love the fact that this game is 6 years old and still amazing. At first I wasn't a fan of the whole pay-to-play" sales model
date: but I completely understand why the dev's did it that way.\n\nIf this game was a "buy once and keep playing" type of game it would have been released in 2009
recommended: and stayed in basically the same shape it was is at the time of release.\n\nInstead
hoursPlayed: we've got a game that is constantly being updated
voteText: even 6 years after it's initial release
helpfulPercent: and that's due to the fact that the devs are still seeing an income from the game
votesHelpful: which allows them to spend time/resourses updating it
votesTotal: and adding fresh new content
votesFunny: as well as fix bugs and add new features over time.\n\nIn my opinion
commentsCount: that makes it worth the $34(CAD) I need to keep paying in order to hunt all the animals after my licenses expire.\n\nDon't get me wrong
column16: if I decide to not pay next year
column17: I can still keep all of the weapons/equipment that came with my initial purchase and use them to hunt Mule Deer and Cottontails (I believe those are the only free animals)
column18: but I will definitely be buying my licenses again next year.\n\nI would even consider buying a higher priced "lifetime license" if the devs ever thought to release something like that
column19: but I understand why they decided to go with the current business model.\n\nNow
column20: if only they would do something similar with theHunter:Primal so it could be anywhere close to as amazing of a game as this is."

reviewText:
So, theHunter, huh. A lot of negativity on this game. You know why it has negativity?

Because most of the people that play this are more used to games like CS:GO, and CoD.

But those who are used to calmer shooting games, I recommend this game.

The Wayfarer Membership is worth the money, though I got the Trailrunner. The game is beautiful and the animals are great. You won't regret your purchase.

You can check the forums for help if you can't find any Mule Deer, the people there are kind and helpful. You could also check the wiki for more information.

Running is only good when you shoot an animal with a firearm, rabbits can't be shot with the .243 ethically, and a lot of people rage bad stuff about this game.

So if you're more of a shoot everything person, don't get this game. But if you're looking for a better hunting game than the Cabela's series, I urge you to get this game.

You won't regret the memberships.

reviewText:
All the complaints about the costs and need for a license make no sense.  For $30 you get all the licenses, unlimited ammo, a few guns and supplies.  It is worth every penny.

I am not sure why this is a problem when you dont have a problem spending twice as much for other games like GTA, Arma, etc. this game is as much fun with a variety of games (competitions and missions) within the game.

Yes. the game costs money but it is worth every penny.

reviewText:
The really astounding thing about this game is how much fun it could be if the company at the reigns wasn't so money grubbing and stupid. It's actually kind of fun to run around, explore, etc. It reminds me of STALKER, only filled with deer and rednecks instead of muties and Russians.

But you get nothing. You get absolutely nothing as a starting player. The only thing you can hunt are mule deer and rabbits, but you can't even kill the rabbits with your rifle. Great decision there. The clothes you start with are vastly inferior to the ones you can only get with money. Which would be fine, but you can't upgrade at all without money. At all. You can't get any weapons, clothes, etc.

The game says you can 'earn' currency by doing surveys and such. This is an absolute load. Every single site it links you to is sketchy as hell. Some of the 'programs' it wants you to download are blatant viruses that only an idiot would use. Nice. Of all the offers I went through ( most of them viruses or dead links that did nothing ), I managed to complete one. I got nothing. The currency never came.

Even if you pay for the game, it's so damn stingy that you're basically going to need to spend money to keep playing. It's absolutely baffling just how much this company hates it's potential players and wants to squeeze every last cent out of them. This isn't free to play. This is a demo. It shouldn't even be in the free to play section.

The only reason you should even consider this game is if you want something to space out to while you're listening to an audiobook or doing something important.

reviewText:
Ok, So I played this game a while back (after developer change but before steam) and would like to say, yes it is a good game. It is a good game with some very nice hunting. But I cannot say it is a great game. There is long walks with nothing to shoot. I have had 3 hour game sessions where I only found one red fox and nothing else despite the fact that I have traversed the entire map and sat for a good while at a stand. Sometimes, there is just a lul in things to shoot. While yes this realistic, can't say it is very fun for a game.

Also, it is very, very expensive to play this game. I can tell you it is almost no fun to play the one map and hunt only the mule deer and ignore all the other tracks and sounds you hear. It is frustrating. Also you can't create multiplayer games and you can't always find multiplayer games that you can hunt in. So it is singleplayer for you. This might actually be a better idea because if you do play multiplayer with strangers, people like to follow you and make lots of noise. It can be maddning to finally find that mule deer, get your sights on him, and then have the guy that had been following you run up, pull up his gun, shoot, and completely miss scaring the deer away and anything else that might be around.

I just think you should be able to do more without spending money or at least have more in-game ways to earn money and buy licenses. I like this game but I can't afford it.
voteText: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It's my first hunting simulation, I really enjoy it and there are a lot of things you can learn from its wiki wich lead you, for example, to a real scoring for mule deers or any other information you didn't know about some species. It is very interesting for those who love hunting simulations. It's realistic, the environment you are in is important in relation to the animal you are hunting and if you miss a move, they're gone but you still can find them later with the track they leave behind. Also, there are a lot of places to go and the maps are big enough to trip trough forests and water.

Why don't I recommend this game?
Because if you want a good equipment, you need to spend a lot of real money or spend some time on third-party pages (eather you earn a little or not... yes, some links does not simply reward you). Well, you earn some virtual cash when you finish a mission but, you can not even buy a thing that is worth your work and time in-game. I don't even know how dare they call this game a F2P. When you are a beginner and don't want to give a few bucks, the only thing that can be done is tracking or kill one of the 18 species (you must have licenses for them ->money) with a single default rifle and there are a lot of missions to do but you can't complete them because you don't really want to spend your own money on that...

Again, it's a very interesting game but the store and monetary system in-game made me sick...

reviewText: It's a good game - don't get me wrong. It's immersive, tense, beautiful, and fun. Tracking is an absolute thrill as well. It's a game I'd gladly pay $15-20 for. However, it's free to play, but not in a good sense. In order to have any real fun after the first hour or two, you'll need to pay ridiculous fees. You wanna hunt something besides mule deer and rabbits? You need to buy liscences with real money for individual animals. Even better, the liscences aren't even permanent! Plus, you need to buy lures, scents, camouflage, and even AMMO! On the plus side" you can allow companies to fill your computer up with malware for some free ingame cash.\n\nTL;DR
date: it'd be great without tons of arbitrary paywalls"

reviewText:
Just no, for the first few hours you do get a slight buzz, and it really does interest me but, after these hours the game just stops. This seriously disappointed me as i soon realize what you need to get a full immersive action: a membership of 3, 6 or 12 months, other guns as (the one you are given is only allowed to be used on a few animals), scopes for the guns and ammunition these all have a sizable price tag and i haven't even mentioned clothes and other addons to make the hunting easier. this may sound like a rant, and it probably is, but it is just annoying that they claim to be a free to play(by definition, a game which gives players access to a significant portion of their content without paying) which is clearly not fufliled in this supposedly free to play game and the developers should be quite ashamed in portraying it to be so (reading through the features they have given, there is no mention of only being able to shoot one animal and only limited to one park for guest).

on the other hand if you are willing to pay on the region of $40 to have enjoyable experience then i am sure you will have a great experience, but withn the next few months or maybe a year you will have to pay another $20 or more to kepp you going on the bare minimum or to get the next urgrade, gun or membership.

back on to those who do not want to pay, like me, you should download this game; just to see if you like it because it is your decision which is the ultimate decider, but do not come into this game thinking you will get a sizeable portion of content as you will be severly disappionted. This is a good game in theory and with the willing to pay constant money, but it underacheives what is expected of an average F2P.

reviewText:
The Hunter is a hunting simulator where your goal is to simply collect the highest scoring animal (in short).
It features a wide range of animals to hunt from small game to big game in different environments.
This combined with new daily competitions to win trophies and in-game cash creates a fun and non-repetitive experience.
It is also being constantly updated with new gear, animals and places to hunt at, and if you don't like playing alone there's also multiplayer. Players can enter different teams in a multiplayer game and compete with eachother.
The graphics are also outstanding and it's a really immersive experience and definitely the best hunting simulator to date.
I've been playing this since early 2012 and will keep playing for years i'm sure.
If I had to give it a grade it would be around 95/100, there's no perfect 100/100 game, every game has its flaws, no matter how small they may be. But in this genre you won't find a better game than The Hunter.

reviewText:
A few years ago I was searching the Internet for hunting games and I stumbled upon theHunter. I played the game for a fairly long time, since it was a one of a kind hunting simulation. First I started as a guest (it's a kind of trial membership) but I became bored pretty fast, since you only can hunt one species (mule deer) and only have one gun. If you're willing to pay for a real membership, you can hunt all the species in the game and also get a couple weapons and unlimited ammunition for them.

Eventually the company behind theHunter became kinda greedy and that changed the whole game literally. If you want to enjoy the whole game and want to take part in all competitions, you have to invest a good amount of money. For example, you don't have to buy every single weapon but then you'll have a limited selection of competitions you can participate in. You don't have to buy every lure or whatever but then you have a disadvantage against other players, who bought all the stuff you're not willing to buy and use.

Long story short: The free" version of the game is just a playable demo in my opinion. If you really want to have fun in theHunter

reviewText:
A few years ago I was searching the Internet for hunting games and I stumbled upon theHunter. I played the game for a fairly long time, since it was a one of a kind hunting simulation. First I started as a guest (it's a kind of trial membership) but I became bored pretty fast, since you only can hunt one species (mule deer) and only have one gun. If you're willing to pay for a real membership, you can hunt all the species in the game and also get a couple weapons and unlimited ammunition for them.

Eventually the company behind theHunter became kinda greedy and that changed the whole game literally. If you want to enjoy the whole game and want to take part in all competitions, you have to invest a good amount of money. For example, you don't have to buy every single weapon but then you'll have a limited selection of competitions you can participate in. You don't have to buy every lure or whatever but then you have a disadvantage against other players, who bought all the stuff you're not willing to buy and use.

Long story short: The free" version of the game is just a playable demo in my opinion. If you really want to have fun in theHunter

reviewText:
Four doctors go out duck hunting. The GP sees a duck, and asks the Physician if it was a duck.
The Physician unsure and asks for a second opinion, whether it was a common duck, a wood duck, a water fowl, a pheasant or a quail,
Then the Surgeon shoots five birds with six shells. BLAM, BLAM, BLAM, … BLAM, BLAM, BLAM, Handing the remains to the Pathologist, he orders “Here, see if you can find a duck.”

You are the hunter, you have your basic rifle, plenty of ammunition, deer call, binocs, and a handi-dandy pocket hunter.

Soon you learn that the HunterMate can help you to track animals and the red semicircular and dome shapes on the ground are actually animal tracks. So out you go from the camp… You want a mule deer, not the female but the big male, to hang his antlers on your wall. You hear a call, but (according to the HunterMate) it’s a whitetail deer. Forget that, so eventually you find a few female mule deer and you follow them down to the Bayfront of what (I imagine) is a wilderness of Washington State. There is a beautiful scenario, a male mule deer standing on the waterfront, but you are too far out cause your rifle is shaking around. He spooks and flees, so you track him for a while, then you lose his trail, damn.

So you go up into the hills, and you spot another two mule deer bucks. Which one is bigger you ask yourself. It is raining, but you don’t let that put you off. Then you lose both of them, oh dear. So you go back down to the cliffs and spot another few females and you follow them for a while before you lose interest and go home.

Next time in the camp, the weather is good, you find the range so you pop off a few rounds and hit the targets out to 100 meters. Full of confidence you head out again and repeat the above scenario. But every once-in-a-while…. You spot the mule deer buck and he hasn’t seen you yet so you move in quietly controlling your breath for the hunt. Then you get into position and he looks up at you - the Hunter, and you take the shot, he drops and you move in inspect your kill. Is he still there? Yep your bullet went through his lung, heart and spine from 43.6 m. Triumph! You think “Thank God the animal didn’t suffer”.

Sometimes you miss “The Shot” and the animal does suffer a lot, blood everywhere and when you find him tired and confused, and he looks up at you, his eyes pleading to end the suffering, well -perhaps some psychiatric counselling may help, you not the animal.

What I don’t understand, is why the ammunition is free. Everything else is pay to use: licences, weapons and supplies, clothes, etc.  You should have to pay for your ammo! Something like say 30 bucks for a thousand rounds for your favourite rifle, should last a while might even allow discounts on your other supplies. This is a great game about hunting and that really captures the spirit of hunting, and getting that one perfect shot.

The Multiplayer game is about camaraderie, working together in teams of hunters to improve your hunt. Or whatever you say it is - such as a hunting competition…

Good game. I have played over 26 hours and taken only 5 shots with three kills, plus I “accidently” shot a rabbit. Honest, Doc I was just checking the scope and the gun went off.
Is it worth paying an annual fee to hunt more animals with a better variety of weapons and equipment? I don’t know I have not done that yet but it is tempting.

Anyways I am off to go and get a first aid kit because I witnessed a feral hog maul a good mate to death, not pretty.

reviewText:
I have been into PC hunting games since the mid 90’s. Then in 1997 Deer Hunter brought it all to 3D. I have owned and played every game in that series from Deer Hunter in 1997 up to Deer Hunter Tournament in 2008 also Trophy Hunter 2003. Then I caught word of a new revolutionary hunting simulation that was in development called theHunter. They have taken PC hunting simulation into the next generation with its release back in 2009. Players have 7 large hunting reserves to choose from that range from open fields to deciduous and evergreen forest also from spring/summer environments to fall and winter. Free to play members can hunt mule deer and cottontail rabbit (2 of the 18 species available) on 2 different reserves. theHunter is new to Steam and a lot of people who seem to think that the gaming industry revolves around Steam also think that if it’s new on Steam then it is new everywhere. This is not the case. theHunter went live sometime back in 2009. Avalanche created a child company called Expansive Worlds solely to further develop theHunter. This shows that the company is passionate about this game and truly believes in its success.
First Impression: I admit before entering the game for the first time I had my doubts about it seriously being much better than the Deer Hunter series gameplay wise and graphically. WOW! Was I ever wrong? Once I wondered away from the starting lodge and into the woods I found myself inspecting all the elements of the environment and vegetation. Astounded at the amount of progress that was made graphically for a hunting simulation. Then I hear a mule deer buck call off in the distance breaking me from my trance. Once that bucked stepped into view the rest is history. Here I am now in 2014 still actively playing the game nearly every day since its release in 2009 currently with 1057 hours of gameplay time.
Free to play: theHunter is Free to Play. This is a very touchy subject for players. It does have 2 species on 2 reserves that are free to hunt. The mule deer and the Cottontail Rabbit can be hunted on 2 different reserves after completing missions for GM$ to buy the single shot 12 gauge shotgun. The downside is that you will also need to purchase the ammunition. My opinion is that if it can be purchased by EM$ or GM$ then ammunition should be unlimited. theHunter does offer very limited free content of the game. On the other side you have to take into account that the game is continuously in development with a team devoted to it. Which requires a steady flow of income.
Membership: theHunter offers 3 basic memberships for 3, 6 and 12 months. 3 package memberships for 3 (Wayfarer), 6 (Pathfinder) and 12 (Trailrunner) months, each with a selection of equipment. Many argue that the cost of the game is high. Here I strongly disagree. In reality even with the membership cost and further micro transactions the game does not cost any more than a normal gaming entertainment budget. Most subscription based online games cost anywhere from $10-19/m, a cost of $120-144/y. Even console games that are released regularly will cost $45-60 for each new game and are released about once a year. The cheapest basic membership at theHunter costs $9.99 for 3 months which is $3.33/m or $39.96/y. A nice difference versus paying $45-144/y. Now take the Trailrunner membership, theHunter’s most expensive option. It is 12 months of membership and starter items for $49.99 which is $4.17/m. At least $5 cheaper than most subscription games per month and at least $70/y. Once your 12 month Trailrunner membership runs out you can renew with a 12 month basic membership for $34.99 which is $2.92/m. That is atleast $10 cheaper than a new console game or atleast $85 cheaper than 1 year for most other sub based games. The amount difference you saved playing theHunter versus the newest console game or most other sub based games can be used to buy any extra items you may want to spice up your inventory with. You can either play theHunter cheaper than most other games, just about the same cost or even more. It is all up to you as a player to decide.
Weapons: There are 15 rifles, 5 handguns, 6 shotguns, 4 bows, a crossbow and a muzzleloader. All have scopes and sights that can be fitted to them. You really only need 1-2 weapons to ethically hunt every species. Buying more just adds variety to your arsenal. So do not be alarmed by these posts saying you need $300 to purchase all weapons. All of the weapons are not necessary to have but an option.
Clothing: Some clothing is purely cosmetic meaning that it offers no such advantage while other clothing such as the Basic Set variants, Boone & Crockett, Army Set, Trapper Set, Doc Monsignor Set and the Ghillie Suit offer different advantages over certain or all species for different types of vegetation. Those advantages are Scent reduction, Visual reduction and Sound reduction. Not every set is a must have. Hunting close range is where these specialized clothing sets have the biggest advantage. When purchasing clothing sets I can highly recommend the Bundles section in the store for a discounted price.
Equipment: Here you have a good variety of items at your disposal. Optics such as binoculars, range finders and a compact digital camera. Consumables such as wind indicator, scent eliminator, camping supplies (for fast travel to tents) and first aid kits. theHunter does have some dangerous game that will charge you. These are moose, feral hog, wild boar, black bear and brown bear. If attacked you will need a first aid kit to continue or you must travel to the nearest lodge or tent (if you have camping supplies).
Play modes: theHunter has Single player and Multiplayer. You can create a multiplayer game for you and up to 7 of your friends to hunt together. There are missions you can complete for GM$. These can be completed in both single player and multiplayer.
Competitions: theHunter offers competitions for every species in the game, except for Cottontail Rabbit. Competitions for new species are introduced a short time after the species release. Competitions are for both Single and Multiplayer. They all offer a small amount of EM$ and a trophy for finishing in 1st, 2nd or 3rd . Special events are run giving awards for the top 10 finishers. During certain holidays special run events or missions will be run. There are also private hosted competitions by members of theHunter, myself included. These generally are listed in the Competition forum at theHunter forums. These offer better pay-outs for the top finishers than the official competitions. Some useful places to find these private competitions are here: http://thehuntercomps.se/, {LINK REMOVED}Derpy Competitions and White Out Hunting[www.whiteouthunting.enjin.com].
The Community: The player community is very friendly and helpful. Players have devoted a lot of personal time into the forums, theHunter Wiki and other fan pages. Theres alot helpful game information in the forums, the wiki, guides, videos and some even do live streaming of the game.
The Development Team: Last but definitely not least the development team. This group of men and women have done an outstanding job bringing us the best hunting simulation there is and will continue to do so. They keep us updated weekly as to what is happening behind the scenes. Each week there is also a game update. This can be bug fixes or larger updates such as new items, species or reserves. Proof that our support is being put to good use.
I hope this will help you to decide to stay and help support a great game despite many negative reviews it has received from the Steam community. Use what is given as free content to help you further decide if this game is worth it. Every one of the 1000+ hours and the money I have invested in the game has been well worth it.

reviewText:
I believe this game is for a certain type of player. First if you are impatient this game is not for you. If you crave constant action then you probably won't like this. If you don't want to spend any money then this is not for you. If you like to hunt, enjoy the reward of patiently stalking and killing something, have some money to spend; then you will probably like this.

I'll comment first about the gameplay then about the pricing of the free to play" in the second/third paragraph.

The game has a slower pace to it
date: I'll give an example of a typical hunt for me. I spawn at a lodge and load up my equipment in my inventory; I'm hunting whitetail and maybe turkey today so I want my shotgun for versatility and bow for stealth
recommended: I could take my .243 rifle but I prefer the shotgun. It's early in the morning and I can see the misty dew settling on the grass plains. The air feels fresh as I slowly wander about looking for my sign. A red tracker mark over some footprints point me in the way of a deer and I walk after it. I want to rush and sprint but I must be patient lest I spook it away. Droppings indicate to me how far it might be
hoursPlayed: more footprints help me close in on it when I hear the grunt of a buck. I crouch down and sit. I could stalk it down
voteText: but I'd rather the deer come to me. I pull out my deer call and mimic the sound of a doe to the open air. A call from the buck responds in kind. The bucks grunts get louder and louder
helpfulPercent: I know which way he's coming from but there is too much brush in the way. I lay down amongst some grass to make my profile even smaller and wait for him to reveal himself. At last I spot him standing tall and he calls out for the doe in my trap. He is still too far out so I maneuver onto a small hill for a better vantage while he gently and slowly walks in. I watch him closely and load a shell of buckshot into my shotgun

votesTotal: nothing special

commentsCount: I know my role as assassin well and wait for him to close in  enough to see the grain of his antlers. Finally he stops before me and raises his head high as I hold my breath to steady the shot. Silence tells him nothing until a cacophonous blast reverberates through the air and scares away any nearby animals from the king as he falls to his knees and lands his face in the dirt. I pull out my huntermate

there's plenty out there yet on the reserve today.

column44: I got a bunch of geese gear. I only hunt with the .243 rifle (given for free) which is good for most deer and coyote and fox. A 12 gauge shotgun
column45: which can shoot anything except birds with slugs and birdshot can shoot those (you get three kinds of shells and it replenishes for every trip). So yes
column46: with one shotgun you can shoot any animal in the game
column47: given somewhat limited range. Finally a compound bow which is great for stealth and when you have multiple animals coming as it won't scatter them like a gun. So my method is very up close and personal usually but only took the purchase of the bow; the pump-action shotgun came with a membership bundle. If you want to hunt big game with a rifle get something up in the .300 caliber range and you're good to go.\n\nSo as a result: Good game for patient gamers who have decent income. Bad game for someone looking for an actual free-to-play game like War Thunder or LoL and/or doesn't like somewhat realistic hunting. Of course you can always try it out yourself. Do the tutorials when you start it up (Hunt Now -> Tutorials) Also read up on the wiki (thehunterwiki.com) has a lot of useful information. If you do decide to get into the game and put down money. I recommend one of the membership bundles
column48: you get a lot more than getting it individually.\n\nIf this review isn't helpful please comment why and I'll do my best to improve it with what you need to know."

reviewText:
After reading all the negative reviews i had to download and see for myself.


After walking around in the game for about an hour i have relized the following.

This is like real life. If you dont have the papers to kill something, you cannot kill it. THe only animal i saw was a bunny, and i wasent allowed to kill it.

Even if i was able to who would hunt bunny with a .243? You would be lucky to get a lucky rabbits foot out of the thing.

The game is beautiful so if you want a game that you can wander around and look at trees, this is the game for you.
If your goal is to shoot deer, dont bother downloading.

Then again it was only a 3gig download so it didint take all day.

reviewText:
I am an avid hunter in Northern Arizona. This game makes me feel like I am actually hunting that nice big mule deer. But the game is not free to play. When you get it you are only allowed to hunt mule deer and rabbit in only one area of the game. If you want to hunt other animals you have to pay for licenses, and the weapons to hunt those animals.

To advertise a game like this as a free to play is wrong. It should be advertised as a free to win game as the only way to get that big whitetail, moose, or elk is to buy a membership, then spend cash for coins to buy bigger and better guns.

I recommend the game if you like great graphics and the feeling of outdoors, but not as a hunting game. Buy one of Cabela's games. Everything is included and you don't have to spend over 200.00 to get great stuff.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Well I'm pretty sure I played this game before, the first map looked very familiar, which was very discouraging as the last time I saw no animals at all.
This time I played the tutorials that weren't there before and they went well. Then I went off to try and hunt.
Found a bunch of deer, yet every shot I took my gun lowered and I got a message saying I have no license.
After a bit of investigating I found out all about the supposed licensing. The free" part consists of 1 type of deer and a type of bird.
Went and looked further and decided I'll try the $10US membership so I got all licenses.
After that I went back and things went down hill. Spent quite a few hours playing and the more time went by the less animals I found. Some times I'd be following a track and suddenly the "huntermate" would turn me around or loop over the previously found track. Other time the track I was looking for wasn't actually in the direction I was pointed and other times it'd just go cold out of nowhere. Some "mate" that is.
On the way back to the camp I see a turkey out of nowhere and so shoot it
date: to which I get told off for an "unpermitted hit" for using the wrong ammo. So I leave and go to the shop to find all the ammo costs more real money along with every other item.\nGoing to uninstall this
recommended: and if I could I'd have my $10 back too.\nSteam should also remove the "free to play tag" since 99% isn't free."

reviewText:
By far one of the best hunting games you will ever find period! Yes it sucks you have to actually buy licenses and rifles and such but in this day and age you should expect it and compared to paying $30 for an arcade cabellas game every few months its worth it. The 3 month is $15 and that is crazy cheap for an online multiplayer game.

As for the game itself. The maps are beautiful and very detailed, most hunting games are either open fields or forrests that seem more like a crop or plantation. Wide selection of firearms and bows, you don't need every single one you can get one rifle and one shotgun and hunt everything in the game, or just one bow. The animals can be a challenge to track more so the trophy animals they are very skiddish as they should be.

Too many people are focusing and giving bad reviews on the fact that this game isnt really free". I have news for you. It is. You never have to buy the game. Yes you have to put a few bucks in here and there to get everything the game has to offer but you dont HAVE to do that if you don't want. Some people just like hunting mule deer... That is FREE... Ammo for the .243 is FREE
date: You want to go hunt whitetail then pay a couple bucks and get a license or pay $15 and get it for 3 months.\n\nIf this game does not suit you then go back to Cabellas games. They are great if you like to hunt like you are playing CoD and not actually hunting."

reviewText: im goinging to explain to some ppl out there with this game and why so negitive. it is one of the best hunting games out there period i have issue's with some bugs and glitches but are doing what they can to find them so far from what i seen. the free2play is off yes but the money isnt all that bad when you consider how much you pay for games that is that is in a continous state of alpha, $15 for 3 months is not bad considering you pay that in some games like wow. a month and you get a shotgun to hunt which with the ammo provided with the shotgun you can hunt all animals. yes you put alittle money into it but if you or someone you know throw's down a 150 bucks to bid into an alpha like archeage then ffs 15 bucks for 3 months shouldnt break your arm. i like it and would recommend to others . great game!

reviewText:
I've played a lot of Hunting Simulator games in my time and this one was by FAR the best one I've ever come across. There are plenty of animals (with great behavioral mechanics), weapons, levels, and good ol' trophy kill satisfaction to keep you occupied for a long time.

Unfortunately the pay-forever-to-play business model ruins it. They took it way too seriously with the word 'simulator', meaning it simulates everything, even the crap parts of real hunting like having to fork out real money for temporary hunting licences.
They argue that many people don't play a game for more than a year, hence the justification" of having to pay the cost of a full-game every year. But I've been playing Deer Hunter 2005 since 2005 and thanks to this game's poor business model I'll still be playing it in 2015. That's the kind of decated fans they are turning off with this payment method.
"

reviewText:
I was bored one night so I gave this one a go.

I find this game a lot more realistic than many of the other hunting games I've played in the past. Granted I spent (however long this says I played it) stalking one single animal, I did not achieve shooting it.

I have, however, achieved locating these animals while sifting through countless piles of scat droppings.

reviewText:
The only hunting simulator worth playing out there at the moment!

The Hunter couples gorgeous graphics and immersive sound design to create vast environments that feel real when you step into them, something that other hunting games out there just don’t replicate.
Recent hunting games have been shoe-horning you down corridors while Ibex and Lions jump out onto your shotgun barrel. The Hunter gives you the opportunity to experience the journey, a complete hunting scenario: Listening out for calls, tracking, and observation, not just constantly providing a slurry of beautiful beasts to bludgeon.

I believe the game suffers when informing new comers. I’d recommend checking out the wiki before jumping in as there are some rules for Guest players who haven’t purchased a membership regarding what you can hunt and where. I have all confidence in the Dev team though! They are constantly active and seem to value and utilise feedback. New content is always on the horizon whether it is new gear, weapons, species or reserves to hunt. The game also boasts a strong community to hunt alongside or against in an interesting array of hunting challenges.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
OverviewIm sorry theHunter, I played this game after playing the amazing theHunter: Primal, and the second I loaded up the game I was dissappointed. The UI looks crappy and movement seems to be much, much slower. If you think Im comparing it too much to Primal, then look at it this way. Movement is fairly slow in Primal, so in this one it feels like you are tip-toeing through the grass, even when you are running. Its also harmed by quite possibly the worst free 2 play business model I have ever seen. I just couldn't bring myself to play much of this game. However, I will say that when creating a profile with theHunter it is quite nice to pick an avatar for your character.

Positive
+ Character customisation

Negative
- Character Movement
- Crappy looking UI
- Hunting Licenses (Business Model)

ConclusionI feel quite sad for having had to leave this review, quite simply because I love theHunter: Primal so much, it makes me feel grateful that it turned out so good, even in early access. You should definitley not download this game, it hardly even counts as f2p.

reviewText:
-Free to play no, very restricted demo yes. On the Loggers Point reserve you can hunt mule deer and rabbits but only get a gun for the rabbits.

-Pay to win no, typical subscription game yes, and at around $3.33 a month and continuous updates I see this as a great value.

-Extra equipment too costly no, able to purchase a whole crap tonne of mini expansions yes. When I first started I bought the entry level bundle for $15 and $10 worth of in game money. I got exactly what I wanted to hunt with for $5 less than the medium bundle. It's not like you go to your sporting goods store and buy all their equipment and guns, the same goes here. I almost feel like buying equipment in this game is like buying tabletop wargaming minis. You end up choosy and the choices have meaningful merit.

-The Havok engine is outstanding in 3d (fallout, Skyrim etc). Where most games can hinder you playing in 3d I have a hard time playing this without using it.

The wiki, be sure to look up permitted ammo types
http://www.thehunterwiki.com/index.php?title=Main_Page

The.de one which seems more focused on mechanics (you may need to translate the page)
http://de.thehunterwiki.com/index.php?title=Hauptseite

reviewText:
Hunting games are usually no fun in my opinion, but I feel that 'theHunter' is much more than just a simply hunting game. Despite the game being extremely limited to nonpaying players as to what they may shoot, it does offer a good amount of activities to keep entertained. That being said, it does not limit its game world and what it contains, just bars one from registering harvests (term used by the game for collecting a kill). Regardless of the constraints, I find myself addicted to the gameplay, idyllic scenery and animated animals, which I continue going back to explore.

The game consists of exploring, tracking, harvesting and if one fails to down their quarry in the first shot, chasing. There are eighteen animals distributed around seven maps called reserves that anyone may explore. The maps are large enough to keep running into animals and not grow bored as one travels from one hunting spot to the other. Most of the fun is following tracks, spotting and then observing what you find. There are also missions one can complete to earn in-game currency (called Gm$ or 'gems'), and a good amount rewards just for tracking and spotting a listed animal or two.

As said before, the game is free-to-play, limiting nonpaying players to one gun and the ability to hunt all the mule deer they want. Although doing missions could land one with the in-game currency to afford a shotgun, allowing the hunting of cottontail rabbits. Sadly that is the extent of not paying for basic membership. The missions are also finite and some require weapons and hunting license bought with special in-game currency (Called Em$) which is different from money gained through missions.

Even with these restrictions, I recommend giving it a try.

reviewText:
theHunter is one of the most enjoyable and most beautiful hunting games available at this time IMO of course. The realistic aspect is not to far extreme where you find yourself waiting a whole day to bag and tag a single animal, but at the same time not at all arcade-y where you can gun down 5 deer in a matter of seconds. The pace of this game is rather rewarding is the sense of accomplishment when it come to the hunt.

The main complaint that many have is there price structure. Yes, it can get expensive purchasing all that is available for this game. In fact If I recall correctly that if you happen to buy everything all at once (not including consumables and a ammo), you are looking at about a $600 price tag.  Yes, a lot of money, but at the same time compare that to Train Simulator 2015 which holds a price tag well over double of theHunter for all of its DLC. This game should not be considered Free-To-Play, but rather Free-To-Test or simple know it as a Demo since you are only allowed to hunt 1 species of deer (Mule Deer) on 1 reserve (Loggers Point). Also some have stated this is a Pay-To-Win game. Far from it IMO. Buying the ingame equipment and such doesnt make you a better hunter than everyone else. You just have more options to hunt and hunt with. Purchasing items in this game is like buying DLC for any other game in the long run. You do get to keep them forever minus consumables, but those can even be purchased with the ingame currency, gm$ which are earned buy completing ingame missions.

At this current time, theHunter is being offered on the Steam Holiday Sale (2014) for 20% off on bundles.  If you have any  form of interest and are willing to support a game that actually works vs. the latest and greatest AAA titles that havent been, now would be a great time to purchase. The largest bundle is currently going for 39.99.  This includes an annual membership that alone cost 35 dollars during the normal time of the year, but also included in this bundle is $85 worth of gear that will allow you to hunt everything and anything under the sun within this game.  Even when the sale lets up, a price tag of 49.99 is not bad. $35 for the annual and $15  for the additional $85 worth of gear.

All and all, I recommend this game to those that enjoy a good hunt and are will to invest a little money (the bundle) into it as you would any other game title that isnt listed as Free-To-Play. After all... games dont make themselves.

reviewText:
Day 1 of the hunt: I left my log cabin with a sniper rifle and 10 bullets. I tracked a deer for 372 miles, and yet I can not find him

Day 2 of the hunt: I saw the deer. I named him Willy. I can never seem to get a good aim at Willy because he never stops moving. Ever.

Day 3 of the hunt: I have been tracking willy for over 900 miles now, and yet he shows no faults in his actions.

Day 374930223932 of the hunt: WILLY WILL DIE. I WILL KILL HIM. I WILL FEAST ON HIS FLESH.

Day 44359803849539583290485039285039458309512903125102 of the hunt: FINALLY. I AM RIGHT BEHIND WILLY, MY SCOPE POINTED AT THE BACK OF HIS HEAD. THIS WILL END NOW. AS I BEGIN TO PULL THE TRIGGER stop, you have attempted to kill a white tailed deer. you do not have a licencse to hunt this animal. you are not permited to kill it.

Day 928488349894823942903509825092840958092834095725928509280928359823095823095820985092850948235947360720967357637563908650927609576872094976072906730976093760972697096702976027602967934709376093760 of the hunt: I am alone in my cabin. I now know the truth. Willy will never die. Willy cannot die. And untill Willy dies, I cannot die.

Day  of the hunt: Willy taunts me. He danses around my cabin. No matter how hard I try I cannot kill Willy. This is it. This is my hell. This is: The Hunter

reviewText: So, I'm back, and this time, an in-depth (not really) review of thehunter. So, yes I know, microtransactions suck, but even if you pay the $15.00 fee for a license(3 months, I believe), you WILL enjoy this game. I happen to find the game really fun. I have decided to buy the $50.00 membership (12 months). The $15.00 and both, the $50.00 plan, come with weapons. The $15.00 comes with a little bit of stuff, but not a load. The $50.00 gives you a bow, two pistols, two shotguns, and two rifles (I may be wrong about that). They both, of course give you a license to hunt all animals and unlimited basic ammo. So if you really don't like the idea of the game, then maybe this will help you face the microtransactions, if you want to play, of course. Thanks for reading this review, this is my opinion of the game, I enjoy playing it, and have collected this informaton since the last time I wrote a review on this game.

reviewText:
Fantastic game!

First things first, If you are expecting COD:FLOOF OPS II, you're going to hate this game.  This is not a game where you will be wandering round the countryside with a .50 calibre Sniper blasting deer and bears into the next world. You do not get to call in air strikes and there isn't action every 2 seconds. Now onto what this game is.

This is THE most realistic hunting simulation around. The countryside is stunning, there are weather and wind conditions to take into account, and if you make a wrong step in the wrong place, the animals will spook. You need to take your time and , well, HUNT ...

If you combine this free game with the Trailrunner pack, you get a 1 year subscription to hunt for every animal, lots of guns and bows to be able to hunt everything and plenty of extra equiptment to aid you in your hunts. You DON'T need the microtransactions if you get this pack, but they are there IF you want them.

£29.99 for a complete hunting simulator, total bargain if you ask me. Just remember, this is a simulator, Try it, download it, run through the first few tutorials and hunt a free animal on your guest pass. If you grow to like it, get the trailrunner pack and you wont need any microtransactions, if you take your time and plan carefully.

reviewText: This game is not a free to play game like it is marked.  It is a free to demo game, allowing you to hunt all species of rabbit, pheasant, and whitetail deer.  Past that you either need to buy licenses, or pay for a subscription.  That being said, the 50$ a year for the game will get you everything you need to hunt every animal in the game.  You will have multiple rifles, shotgun, bow, and pistol to pick from.  If you get the years sub, which i recommend, the rest is up to you on spending.  You can either spend a large amount of money, or join open games to hunt animals that would be difficult to hunt other wise, water fowl.   The only thing i recommend as a must buy after the years sub is the caller bundle.  Everything else you don't need to enjoy the game.  The game is open map, realistic hunting, at its finest.  You can't blast a rabbit w/ a .300 and get a score as its not an ethical round to take the game with.  The tracking is awesome.  The wildlife interaction is awesome.  The reserves are awesome.  The game is very well done, but it definately isnt a free to play game.  There are competition you can join, and if you place in them you can get the equivalent of $ used to purchase more guns, callers, subscriptions, ect.  I believe the game wouldn't have so many negative reviews if it wasnt marked as free to play.  The devs are very active with making new guns, wildlife, reserves, and updating graphics for both animals, and reserves.
